akk: a-na ia-as2-ma-ah-{d}iszkur qi2-bi2-ma um-ma isz-me-{d}da-gan a-hu-ka-a-ma asz-szum ma-a-at szu-szar-ra-a{ki} sza ta-asz-pu-ra-am ki-ma ma-tum szi-i id-da-al-la-hu u3 ku-ul-la-sza la ni-le-u2 {disz}i-szar-li-im li-id-bu-ba-kum {disz}li-da-a-ia _lu2_ tu-ru-ku-u2# u3 _lu2_ tu-ru-ku-u2 sza it-ti-szu sza i-na ma-a-tim sza-a-ti wa-asz-bu ik-ki-ru-ma 2(disz) a-la-ni{ki} ig-mu-ru an-'a4#-ri-ir-ma [a-na] li#-ib-bi _kur_-i i#-ru-bu ni-isz7-ta-al-ma ki-ma ma-tum szi-i
akkts: ana yasmaḫ-addu qibima umma išme-dagan aḫukama aššum māt šušarrâ ša tašpuram kīma mātum šī iddallaḫu u kullaša lā nile’’û išarlim lidbubakkum lidaya awīlum turukkû u awīlum turukkû ša ittišu ša ina mātim šâti wašbū ikkirūma šina ālānī igmurū an’arrirma ana libbi šadî īrubū ništalma kīma mātum šī
en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu speak! Thus Išme-Dagan, your brother: Concerning the country Šušarrâ (about) which you wrote me, since this country is in confusion and we are unable to hold it back, let Išar-Lim speak to you; Lidaya, the Turukkean, and the Turukkean with him who in that country reside, became hostile, and two cities finished off. I came to help, and to the heart of the mountains they entered. We reflected, and since that country

akk: a-na ku-ul-lim la ir-re-du-u2 ma-a-tam sza-a-ti as-[hu-up]-ma [isz-tu ma-a-at] ar#-ra-ap-hi-im{ki} u3 [isz-tu ma-a]-at# qa-ab-ra-a{ki} a-di# [...] li#?-sze-szi-ib-x [s,a-bu-um] sza li-ib-bi ma-tim [ip-pa]-at,#-t,a3-ar [sza-al]-ma#-ku mi-im-ma li-ib-ba-ka [la] i-na-hi-id
akkts: ana kullim lā irreddû mātam šâti asḫupma ištu māt arrapḫim u ištu māt qabrâ adi ... lišešib-x ṣābum ša libbi mātim ippaṭṭar šalmāku mimma libbaka lā inaḫḫid
en: for keeping back would not be led, that country I attacked, and from the country Arrapḫum and from the country Qabrâ up to... let colonize(?). Troops of the heart of the country will be freed. I am well; your heart at all may not fear.

akk: [a]-na ia-as2-ma-ah-{d}[iszkur] qi2#-bi2-[ma] um-ma isz-me-{d}da-gan a-hu-ka-a-ma ki-ma qa-du-um s,a#-bi#-im a-na ne2-e'2-ra-ri-im a-na re-esz sa-mu-{d}iszkur ku-ul-lim a-na ka-ra-na-a{ki} al-li-kam wu-di i-na pa-ni-tim-ma asz-pu-ra-kum _lu2_ esz3-nun-na{ki} qa-du-um ga-ma-ar-ti s,a-bi-szu qa-du-um _giri3-se3-ga-mesz_ u3 be-el du-um-qi2 ip#-hu-ur-ma i-na u2-pe2{ki} [wa]-szi-ib-ma [u3 a-na] _lu2_ babila{ki} [a-na it]-ti-szu ne-en-mu-di-im [i-na ma]-an-ki-si{ki} [...]-x-e-em
akkts: ana yasmaḫ-addu qibima umma išme-dagan aḫukama kīma qadum ṣābim ana ne’rārim ana reš samu-addu kullim ana karanaya allikam wuddi ina panītimma ašpurakkum awīl ešnunna qadum gamarti ṣābišu qadum girseqqî u bēl dumqī ipḫurma ina upe wašibma u ana awīl bābilim ana ittišu nenmudim ina mankisi ...-em
en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu speak! Thus Išme-Dagan, your brother: Since with the troops to aid and support Samu-Addu to Karanaya I went, certainly earlier I wrote to you; the man of Ešnunna with the ensemble of his troops, together with administrative staff and notables, gathered, and in Opis sat, and further to the man of Babylon to meet up with him in Mankisi ...

akk: isz#-ta-ap-pa-ar-ma _lu2#_ babila{ki} u2-ul im-gu-ru-ma qa-du _lu2_ babila{ki} la im#-gu#-ru-szu i-na la bu-usz-ti-szu it-be2-em-ma a-na ma-asz-ku-ul#-li#-ia{ki} il-li-kam-ma i-na ma-asz-ku#-ul-li-ia{ki} a-na _i7_ he-re-e-em qa-as-su isz-ku-un a-lum ma-asz-ku-li-ia{ki} e-le-nu-um bad3-i-pi2-iq-{d}iszkur{ki} i-na _a-sza3_ be2-ra-am sza-ki-in ki-ma a-na ma-asz-ku-li-ia{ki} u2-qe2-ri-ba-am {disz}sa-mu-{d}iszkur isz-pu-ra-am-ma qa-du-um s,a-bi-im a-na a-lim at-ta-ha-ra-am a-na a-lim ak-szu-dam-ma [ki]-ma a-wa-tum ni-i'2-da u3 _lu2_ esz3-nun-na{ki} [a]-na gu-ul-lu-lim pa-ni-szu isz-ku-nu-szu a-na li-bi ma-ti-szu [i]-tu-ru sa-mu-{d}iszkur isz-pu-ra-am-ma [a]-na s,a-bi-im sza it-ti-ia il-li-kam [t,e4]-ma#-am sza t,a3-ra-di-im
akkts: ištapparma awīl bābilim ul imgurma qadu awīl bābilim la imgurušu ina la būštišu itbêmma ana maškulliya illikamma ina maškulliya ana nārim herêm qassu iškun ālum maškulliya elēnum dūr-ipiq-addu ina eqlim bēram šakin kīma ana maškulliya uqerribam samu-addu išpuramma qadum ṣābim ana alim attaḫaram ana alim akšudamma kīma awātum ni’dā u awīl ešnunna ana gullulim pānīšu iškunušu ana libbi mātišu itūru samu-addu išpuramma ana ṣābim ša ittiya illikam ṭēmam ša ṭarādim
en: kept writing, but the man of Babylon did not agree, and although the man of Babylon did not agree, in his shamelessness he rose up against me, and to Maškulliya he went, and in Maškulliya to waterway dredging his hand set. The city Maškulliya above Dūr-ipiq-Addu at a distance of a double-hour set. As I Maškulliya approached, Samu-Addu wrote and with troops to the city I hastened, in the city arrived, and since matters were remarkable, the man of Ešnunna to do evil his face had set, to the heart of the land returned; Samu-Addu wrote me, and to the troops who with me came, report of dispatch,

akk: [a-na s,e]-er sa-mu-{d}iszkur [asz-pu-ur] u3 sza-pi2-il-ti s,a-bi-im [sza i-na] li-bi ma-a-tim isz7-ta-ah-hu
akkts: ana ṣēr samu-addu ašpur u šapilti ṣābim ša ina libbi mātim ištaḫḫu
en: to Samu-Addu I sent; further, the remainder of the troops who in the heart of the land had dispersed;

akk: u3 [...] at-[...] mi-im#-[ma li-ib-ba-ka la i-na-hi-id]
akkts: u ... at-... mimma libbaka lā inaḫḫid
en: further, ... I ..., you need not be at all anxious.

akk: a-na ia-as2-ma-ah-{d}iszkur qi2-bi2-ma um-ma isz-me-{d}da-gan a-hu-ka-a-ma asz-szum ma-la#-ki-ka ta-asz-pu-ra-am szum-ma t,up-pi2 an-nu-u2-um a-na s,e-ri-ka ik-ta-asz-da-kum-ma _u4#_-mu#-um ma-a-ad isz-tu ma-da-ra-a{ki} ['i3]-e#?-er-ma kap-ru-um [da-an]-nu-um i-ba-asz-szi [szu-sze]-ra-am-ma [bi]-i-it
akkts: ana Yasmaḫ-Addu qibima umma Išme-Dagan aḫukama aššum malākīka tašpuram šumma ṭuppī annûm ana ṣērika iktašdakkumma umum mād ištu madaraya ’ierma kaprum dannum ibašši šušeramma bīt
en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu speak! Thus Išme-Dagan, your brother: Concerning your messengers you wrote me. If this my tablet to you arrives, and it will be many days; from Madaraya go, a strong village is there. Go straight in, and house!

akk: u3 ur-ra-am i-na ka-s,a-ti-szu a-na s,e-ri-ia ku-usz-dam u3 _lu2-tur_-ka la-mi-ka li-bu-am li-ih-mu-t,a3-am-ma ki-ma a-na pa-ni-ka a-na tu-usz-hi-im{ki} a-sa-an-ni-qu2 szum-ma la ki-a-am-ma tu-sza-am-szi-ma i-na ma-da-ra-a{ki}-ma ta-ab-ti-it sze-rum sze-ra-am-ma al-kam u3 _lu2-tur_-ka li#-bu-am-ma a-ia-szi-im li-ba-ar-re-e-em ki-ma a-na a-lim a-sa-an-ni-qu2 u3 _dingir-mesz_
akkts: u urram ina kaṣâtišu ana ṣēriya kušdam u ṣuḫārka lamika libû’am liḫmuṭamma kīma ana pānika ana Tušḫim asanniqu šumma la kīamma tušamšima ina madarayama tabtīt šērum šēramma alkam u ṣuḫārka libû’amma ayâšim libarrêm kīma ana ālim asanniqu u ilū
en: Further, the next morning, early, to me come. Further, let your servant before you go along, let him be quick, so that to you at Tušḫum I can approach. If not thus you spent the night, but in Madaraya housed, as early as possible come, and your servant let go along, and just me let him notify. When the city I approach, and the gods

akk: ki-ma ma-la-ki-szu-nu-ma# li-il-li-ku-nim#
akkts: kīma malākīšunuma lillikūnim
en: like their messengers let them come.

akk: a-na ia-as-ma-ah-{d}iszkur qi2-bi2-ma um-ma isz-me-{d}da-gan a-hu-ka#-a-ma# te-re-et# ni#-qi2-i# tu-sza-bi#-lam#-ma a-mu-ur-szi-na-ti u3 ki-a-am# ta-asz-pu#-ra#-am um-ma-mi sza-ma!-an li-ib-bi-im i-mi-tam-ma ta-ri-ik li-ib-bu-um szu-u2 i-mi-tam u3 szu-me-lam ta-ri-ik u3 szi-it-hu-um sza-ki-in te-ri-ik szu-me-lim
akkts: ana yasmaḫ-addu qibima umma išme-Dagan aḫukama têrēt nīqī tušābilamma amūršināti u kiam tašpuram ummami šaman libbim imittamma tarik libbum šū imittam u šumēlam tarik u šitḫum šakin terik šumēlim
en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu speak! Thus Išme-Dagan, your brother: The extisipicies of the sacrifice you sent here, and I saw them; further, in the following way you wrote me, thus: The fat of the center to the right is black; The heart itself to the right and left is dark. Further, a thick scar is there. The dark spot of the left

akk: pi2-qa-at u2-ul u2-ka-al-ka a-nu-um-ma te-re-tim szi-na-ti ut-te-er-ra-kum a-mu-ur-szi-na-ti it-ti te-er-ki pi2-it-ru-su-tim u3 szi-it-hu-um sza-ki-in mi-im-ma u2-ul sza na-'a4-di!-im
akkts: pīqat ul ukâlka anumma têrētim šināti uttērrakkum amuršināti itti terkī pitrusūtim u šitḫum šakin mimma ul ša na’ādim
en: might not concern you. Now, these extispicies I have sent back to you. Read them! With the dark spots, the contradictory (patches), further a thick scar is there. There is nothing to be concerned about.

akk: a-na ia-as2-ma-ah-{d}iszkur qi2-bi2-ma um-ma ap-la-ha-an-da a-hu-ka-a-ma a-nu-um-ma _gesztin du10-ga_ usz-ta2-bi-la-kum u3 szi-ti a-nu-um#-ma _ninda_ sza kar-ka-mi-isz7#[{ki}] u3 a#-ku-ul a-nu-um-ma 1(disz) e-[...] a-nu-um-ma _1(disz) har-szu_ bar-[...] a-nu-um-ma 1(disz) {tug2}su2-nim u3 a-nu#-[um-ma] _1(disz) {tug2}sza3-ga-du3 du8-szi-a_ usz-ta2-bi-la-kum u3 asz-szum a-wa-tim mi-im-ma a-na s,e-ri-ia szi-tap-pa-ra-am u3 a-na-ku a-na ma-an-nim a#-na-at,-t,a3-al#
akkts: ana yasmaḫ-addu qibima umma aplaḫanda aḫukama anumma karānam ṭābam uštābilakkum u šiti anumma aklum ša karkamiš u akul anumma ištēn e-... anumma ištēn semer qātim bar-... anumma ištēn sūnim u anumma ištēn šakattâm dušâm uštābilakkum u aššum awātim mimma ana ṣēriya šitapparam u anāku ana mannim anaṭṭal
en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu speak! Thus Aplaḫanda, your brother: Now good wine I have sent you; so drink! Now bread of Carchemish; so eat! Now 1 ... ; now 1 bracelet ... ; now 1 sūnu(-garment), further now 1 š(-garment) of dušûm(-stone color) I have sent you. Further, for the sake of all the terms to me keep sending! Further, as for me, to whom will I look?

akk: [...]-x-x an-nu-um _e2#_ {d}x-gal [...]-x {d}utu-szi-{d}iszkur a-bi-ia [a-na hi]-sze-eh-ti-ka szu-up-ra-am-ma usz#-ta-bi-la-kum u3  a#-na#? x mi-im-ma# am#-mi-nim la ta#-sza#-ap-pa-ra#-[am] u3 a-bi [...] wa-szi-ib# ia-[...] an-ni-tam u3# [la an-ni-tam] szu-up#-ra#-am#-[ma ...] a-sza#-ap#-[pa-ra-kum]
akkts: ... annûm bīt ... ... šamšī-addu abiya ana ḫišeḫtika šupramma uštābilakkum u ana ... mimma ammīnim lā tašapparam u abī ... wašib ia-... annītam u lā annītam šupramma ... ašapparakkum
en: This ..., the house of ... ... of Šamšī-Addu, my father, per your needs write me, and I have sent to you. and for ... something why do you not send to me? Further, my father in ... is staying; ... One way or the other, write to me, and ... I will send to you.

akk: a-na isz-me-{d}da-gan qi2-bi2-ma um-ma isz-hi-{d}iszkur a-ha-ka-a-ma a-wa-tam an-ni-tam a-na la qa-be2-e-em-ma u3 i-na-an-na lu-uq-bi-ma u3 li-ib-bi lu-na-ap-pi2-i-isz _lugal_ ra-bu-um at-ta 2(disz) _ansze-kur-ra_ e-ri-isz-ta-ka te-ri-sza-an-ni-ma u3 u2-sza-ri-a-kum u3 at-ta 2(u) _ma-na an-na_{a-na-ka-am} tu-sza-bi-lam i-na la da-ba-ba-am i-sza-ri-isz it-ti-ia la ha-asz-ha-ta _an-na_ i-s,a-am an-ni-tam tu-sza-bi-lam szum-ma-an szu-bu-lum-ma la tu-sza-ab-ba-lam asz-szum _dingir_ sza a-bi-ia szum-ma-an li-ib-bi im-ra-as, szi-im _ansze-kur-ra_ a-nu-um-mu-tim it-ti-ni i-na qa-ta-na{ki}
akkts: ana išme-dagan qibima umma išḫi-addu aḫakama awātam annītam ana lā qabêmma u inanna luqbima u libbī lunappiš šarrum rabûm atta šinā sisî erištaka tērišannimma u ušari’akkum u atta ešrā manê annakam tušābilam ina lā dabābam išariš ittiya lā ḫašḫāta annakam īṣam annītam tušābilam šumman šūbulumma lā tušabbalam aššum ilim ša abiya šumman libbī imraṣ šīm sisî annummûtim ittini ina qatana
en: To Išme-Dagan speak! Thus Išḫi-Addu, your brother: This word is unspeakable, yet now may I speak, and further may my heart relax! A great king are you. Two horses as your request you requested from me, and  But as for you, 20 minas of tin you sent to me. To not act straight with me may you not desire! This little tin you sent! If but you were not sending me anything! On account of the god of my father, if but my heart were ill! The price of horses, the aforementioned, with us in Qatna

akk: 6(disz) me-tim _ku3-babbar_-szu-nu u3 at-ta 2(u) _ma-na an-na_ tu-sza-bi-lam u3 sze-mu-u2-um mi-nam i-qa-ab-bi u2-ul i-ta-pa-la-ne2-ti-i _e2_ an-nu-u2-um _e2-ka_ i-na _e2_-ka mi-nu-um ha-t,i3 a!-hu-um a-na a-hi-im e-ri-isz-ta-a-am u2-ul i-na-ad-di-in szum-ma-an _an-na_{a-na-ka-am} la tu-sza-ab-ba-la-am mi-im-ma li-ib-bi u2-la-ma-an im-ra-as, u2-ul _lugal_ ra-bu-um at-ta am-mi-nim an-ni-tam te-pu-usz _e2_ an-nu-u-um _e2_-ka
akkts: šeššet mētim kaspišunu u atta ešrā manê annakam tušābilam u šēmûm mīnam iqabbi ul ītapalnêti bītum annûm bītka ina bītika mīnum ḫaṭi aḫum ana aḫim erištam ul inaddin šumman annakam lā tušabbalam mimma libbī ullāman imraṣ ul šarrum rabûm atta ammīnim annītam tēpuš bītum annûm bītka
en: is 6 hundred (shekels) of silver, but you, 20 minas of tin you sent me. Further, the one who hears, will say what? “He has not dealt so with us.” This house is your house. In your house, what is missing? Does brother to brother a wish not grant? If but tin you were not sending to me! My heart would not have been sick at all. Not a great king are you. Why have you done this? This house is your house.

akk: [a-na be-li2]-ia# ia-as2-ma-ah-{d}iszkur qi2#-bi2-ma um-ma as3-qu2-du-um _ARAD2_-ka-a-ma ki-ma ka-sza-di-ia-ma i-na ter-qa{ki} {disz}ta-ri-im-sza-ki-im-ma ik-szu-dam-ma ki-a-am a-sza-al-szu um-ma a-na-ku-ma te-re-tim a-na szu-lum ma-a-tim u3 a-al da-an-na-tim {disz}zu-na-an i-pu-usz2 szu-u2 ki-'a4-am i-pu-la-an-ni um-ma-mi u2-ul i-pu-usz2
akkts: ana bēliya yasmaḫ-addu qibima umma asqudum waradkama kīma kašādiya ina terqa tarim-šakimma ikšudamma kiam ašālšu umma anākuma têrētim ana šulum mātim u āl dannātim zunan īpuš šū kiam īpulanni ummami ul īpuš
en: To my lord Yasmaḫ-Addu speak! thus Asqudum, your servant: At my arrival in Terqa, Tarim-šakin arrived, and in the following way I asked him, thus I: “The extispicies to the well-being of the land, and the fortresses, did Zunan perform (them)?” That one in the following way answered me, thus: “He did not perform (them).”

akk: i-na te-bi-ib-ti _iti_ an-ni-im it-ti-szu a-na sa-ga-ra-tim{ki} a-tu-ra-ma te-re-tim a-na szu-lum a-lim{ki} sa-ga-ra-tim{ki} a-na _iti 6(disz)-kam_ e-pu-usz2-ma te-re-tum sza-al-ma u3 ki-ma pa-ni-ia-ma i-na _bad3_ be-li2-ia ter-qa{ki} s,u2-up-ri-im{ki} u3 ma-ri{ki} e-pe2-esz-ma t,e4-ma-am ga-am-ra-am ma-ah-re-em-ma a-na s,e-er be-li2-ia [a]-sza#-pa-ra-am [u3] i-na sa-ga-ra-tim [a]-na ni-iq wa-ar-hi-im# [u3 a]-na# ni-iq be-li2-ia [e-pu-usz2]-ma [te]-er#-tam a-mu-ur-ma szu-me-el u2-ba-nim pa#-t,e4-er u2-ba-an ha-szi-i qa-ab-li-tum a-na i-mi3-tim it,-hi szi-ir szu-mi3-im be-li2 lu ha-di
akkts: ina tēbibti warḫim annîm ittišu ana saggaratim atūramma têrētim ana šulum alim saggaratim ana warḫim šeššetim ēpušma têrētum šalmā u kīma pāniyama ina dūr beliya terqa ṣuprim u mari eppešma ṭēmam gamram maḫrȇmma ana ṣēr bēliya ašapparam u ina saggaratim ana nīq warḫim u ana nīq bēliya ēpušma têrtam amurma šumēl ubānim paṭer ubān ḫašî qablītum ana imittim itḫi šīr šūmim bēlī lū ḫadi
en: In the ‘cleansing’ of that month with him to Saggaratum I returned, and extispicies to the well-being of the city Saggaratum to the 6th month I performed, and the extispicies were favorable; further, prior to my (departure) at the Wall of my lord, Terqa, Ṣuprum and Mari, I shall perform (them), and a full report promptly to my lord I will send; further, in Saggaratum for the offering of the month and for the offering of my lord I performed (extispicies), and an extispicy I saw, and the left of the finger was loose; the middle finger of the lungs to the right approached; an omen of fame, my lord may be happy.

akk: [a]-na be-li2-ia qi2-bi2-ma um-ma la-u2-um _ARAD2_-ka-a-ma _iti_ ki-nu-nim _u4 1(u) 2(disz)-kam_ is-su2-uh-ma {disz}sag-{d}nin-bala a-na ma-ri{ki} ik-szu-dam te-re-tim a-na _kaskal_-szu u2-sze-pi2-isz-ma lu-up-pu-ta [...]-isz#-ma
akkts: ana bēliya qibima umma la’um waradkama waraḫ kinūnim ūmum šinšeret issuḫma reš-ninbala ana mari ikšudam tērêtim ana ḫarrānišu ušēpišma lupputā ...-išma
en: To my lord speak! Thus La’um your servant: It is the month of Kinūnum, the 12th day expired, and Reš-Ninbala, in Mari arrived. Extispicies for his journey I had performed, and they were very unfavorable. ..., and

akk: [...]-szu [be-li2] lu-u2 i#-de# [ma-ri{ki}] sza#-lim [ma-a-tum sza]-al-ma#-at#
akkts: ...-šu belī lū īde mari šalim mātum šalmat
en: ... him. My lord should know! Mari is well; the land is well.

sux: pisan-dub-ba zi-ga sza3 {kusz}du10-gan-na sa2-du11 kas4 gur4-za-an muhaldim iti sze-sag11-ku5 mu si-ma-num2{ki}-ta
en: Basket-of-tablets: credits in the pouch, rations of the messengers, Gurzan, the cook, from the month “Harvest,” year: “Simanum,”

sux: iti sze-kar-ra-gal2-la mu bad3 mar-tu ba-du3-sze3 i3-gal2
en: to the month “Barley at the harbor,” year: “The Amorite wall was erected,” are here.

sux: pisan-dub-ba gurum2-ak ab2 e2-tur3 gu4-{gesz}apin udu eme-gi udu kur-ra
en: Basket-of-tablets: inspections, cows of the stall, plow-oxen, sheep, domestic, sheep, foreign,

sux: sipa ud5 gu4-suhub2 i3-gal2 mu hu-uh2-nu-ri{ki} ba-hul
en: shepherds of nannies, boot-oxen, are here; year: “Ḫuḫnuri was destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba e2-szu-szum2-ma nig2-gur11 ur-{d}li9-si4 ensi2 umma u3 dam dumu-na nig2-gur11 {d}szul-gi-ra
en: Basket-of-tablets: house of consignments, property of Ur-Lisi, the governor of Umma and his wife and children, property of Šulgi,

sux: giri3 sza3-ta-ku3-zu sukkal u3 nig2-gur11 bar-ra gaba-ri kiszib3-ba ba-ba-ti i3-gal2 iti {d}dumu-zi mu en eridu{ki}
en: via Šatakuzu, the messenger, and property of outside, copies of sealed tablets of Babati, are here; month “Dumuzi,” year: “The en-(priest) of Eridu.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba sza3-bi su-ga mar-sa giri3 lugal-nir-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: thereins, restitutions, of the shipyard via Lugal-nirgal,

sux: i3-gal2 mu sza-asz-ru{ki} ba-hul
en: are here; year: “Šašru was destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 dab-ba a2 erin2-na ur-{d}nin-su nu-banda3-gu4 iti 1(u) 2(disz)-kam
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents of dab, labor of (labor-)troops, Ur-Ninsu, manager of oxen, (a period of) 12 months,

sux: i3-gal2 mu bad3 mar-tu ba-du3
en: are here; year: “The Amorite wall was erected.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 ur-{d}nin-tu u3 szesz-saga mu en ga-<esz>{ki} u3 mu {d}szu-{d}suen lugal
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents of Ur-Nintu and Šeš-saga of the year: “Ga’eš,” and the year: “Šu-Suen is king,”

sux: i3-gal2
en: are here.

sux: pisan-dub-ba nig2-ka9-ak lu2-du10-ga ugula mu e2 {d}szara2 ba-du3
en: Basket-of-tablets: accounts of Luduga, the foreman, year: “The house of Šara was erected.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba zi-ga sze i3-gal2 iti ezem-{d}amar-{d}suen-ta u4 2(u) 4(disz)-am3 ba-ra-zal-la-ta
en: Basket-of-tablets: credits of barley, are here; from the month “Festival-of-Amar-Suen,” 24th day passed,

sux: mu {d}amar-{d}suen lugal-e sza-asz-szu2-ru-um{ki} mu-hul-ta
en: year: “Amar-Suen, the king, Šaššurum destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kasz-de2-a u3 ninda szu-ur3-ra {d}szul-gi-ra i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: Beer ceremonty and Bread-spread of Šulgi are here;

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 dab-ba na-u2-a mu 1(disz) iti 5(disz)-kam i3-gal2 mu en-mah-gal-an-na-ta
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents of dab, Na’ua (a period of) 1 year 5 months, are here; from the year: “Enmaḫgalana”

sux: mu en-unu6-gal {d}inanna ba-hun iti 5(disz)-sze3
en: to the year: “Enunugal of Inanna was hired,” 5 months.

sux: pisan-dub-ba nig2-ka9-ak u3 kiszib3 dab-ba-bi ur-{d}en-lil2-la2 i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: accounts and their sealed documents of dab of Ur-Enlila, are here;

sux: mu {d}amar-{d}suen lugal-e sza-asz-szu2-ru-um{ki} mu-hul
en: year: “Amar-Suen, the king, Šaššurum destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 dabx(U8)?-ba uruda nig2-sziti-ma u3 dam-gar3 ki da-da-ga-ta
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents of dab, copper of ..., and trade agents, from Dadaga,

sux: mu 1(disz)-a-kam i3-gal2 mu ha-ar-szi{ki} ki-masz{ki} ba-hul
en: 1 year, are here; year: “Ḫarši Kimaš were destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba nig2-ka9-ak ugula {d?}szara2-kam ugula iti 1(u) 3(disz)-kam i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: accounts, foreman Šarakam, foreman, (a period of) 13 months, are here;

sux: mu {d}szu-{d}suen lugal-e e2 {d}szara2 umma{ki} mu-du3
en: year: “Šu-Suen, the king, the house of Šara in Umma erected.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba nig2-ka9-ak lu2 <nig2>-dab5-ba-ke4-ne sza3 pisan a-a-kal-la ensi2-ka
en: Basket-of-tablets: accounts of the dab workers, in the basket of Ayakalla, the governor,

sux: i3-gal2 mu {d}szu-{d}suen lugal uri5{ki}-ma-ke4 ma-da za-ab-sza-li{ki} mu-hul
en: are here; year: “Šu-Suen, king of Ur, the lands of Zabšali destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 dabx(U8)?-ba a2 erin2-na-ka lugal-ku3-zu nu-banda3-gu4 iti 1(u) 4(disz)-kam iti sze-sag11-ku5 mu na-ru2-a-mah ba-du3-ta
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents of dab, labor of the (labor-)troops, Lugal-kuzu, manager of oxen, (a period of) 14 months, from month “Harvest,” year: “Big-Stele was erected”

sux: iti sze-sag11-ku5 mu ma-da za-ab-sza-li{ki} ba-hul-sze3 mu na-ru2-a-mah ba-du3
en: to month “Harvest,” year: “The lands of Zabšali were destroyed,” year: “Big-Stele was erected.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba im e2-tum sze gesz e3-a mu us2-sa {d}szu-{d}suen lugal uri5{ki}-ma-ke4 bad3 mar-tu mu-ri-iq-ti-id-ni-im mu-du3-a
en: Basket-of-tablets: tablets, ‘chambers,’ threshed barley, year following: “Šu-Suen, king of Ur, the Amorite wall (called) mūriq-tidnim erected,”

sux: i3-gal2
en: are here.

sux: pisan-dub-ba en3-bi tar-re e2-usz-bar-ra u3 kiszib3 ra-ra a-a-kal-la
en: Basket-of-tablets: inquiries of the weaving mill and sealed documents of Ayakalla,

sux: szesz i3-kal-la i3-dab mu en {d}inanna unu{ki} masz-e i3-pa3
en: brother of Ikalla, accepted, year: “The en(-priest) of Inanna in Uruk by the goat was found.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 nam-sza3-tam lu2 <nig2>-dab5-ba-ke4-ne i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents, official, of the men of nigdab, are here;

sux: mu ha-ar-szi{ki} ki-masz{ki} ba-hul
en: year: “Ḫarši Kimaš were destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba nig2-ka9-ak sze-numun u3 GAN2 uru4-a nigin-ba-bi
en: Basket-of-tablets: accounts, seed grain and fields in plow, their grand totals

sux: i3-gal2 mu en {d}inanna masz-e i3-pa3
en: are here; year: “The en-(priest) of Inanna by the goat was found.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba dub-gid2-da ka-tar-{d}ba-ba6 ur-ba-gara2 lu2-{d}isztaran
en: Basket-of-tablets: long-tablets of Katar-Baba, Ur-bagara, Lu-Ištaran,

sux: lu2-{d}lamma <ugula>-gesz2-da u3 lu2-{d}nin-gir2-su mu ur-bi2-lum{ki}
en: Lul-Lamma, foreman of sixty, and Lu-Ningirsu, year: “Urbilum.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba e2-tum gesz ku3-ta du8-ha mu ha-ar-szi{ki} hu-ur5-ti{ki}
en: Basket-of-tablets: ‘chambers,’ ..., year: “Ḫarši Ḫurti.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 dabx(U8)?-ba gi ARAD2-e-eb i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents of dab, reed, ARAD-eb, are here;

sux: pisan-dub-ba nig2 zi-zi bala 2(disz)?-kam i3-dub
en: Basket-of-tablets: things for credits, 2nd bala, silos,

sux: mu kar2-har{ki} a-ra2 3(disz)#?-kam-asz ba-hul u3 mu dumu-munus lugal ensi2 an-sza-an-na ba-an-tuku
en: year: “Karhar for the 3rd time was destroyed,” and year: “The princess to the governor of Anšan was married.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba bar-ra-kar-ra i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: Barakara are here;

sux: mu {gesz}gu-za {d}en-lil2-la2 ba-dim2
en: year: “The chair of Enlil was fashioned.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba dub-gid2-da lu2-{d}utu sa12-du5 i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: long-tablets of Lu-Utu, chief surveyor, are here;

sux: mu si-mu-ur4-ru-um{ki} lu-lu-bu{ki} a-ra2 1(u) la2 1(disz)-kam-asz ba-hul
en: year: “Simurum Lulubu for the 9th time were destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba sag-nig2-gur11-ra sza3-bi su-ga mu-kux(DU) {d}szara2 a-pi4-sal4{ki} giri3 sza3-ku3-ge kiszib3? a-ru-a
en: Basket-of-tablets: debits, therefroms, restitutions, deliveries to Šara of Apisal, via Šakuge sealed documents, offerings,

sux: i3-gal2 mu bad3 mar-tu ba-du3
en: are here; year: “The Amorite wall was erected.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba siki-ba szu-du7-a sza3 umma{ki} u3 sza3 a-pi4-sal4{ki} i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: wool rations, completed, in Umma and in Apisal, are here;

sux: mu sza-asz-ru{ki} ba-hul
en: year: “Šašru was destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 dab?-ba kiszib3 nam-sza3-tam [...] nam a-sza3 <a>-pi4-sal4 u3 gu2-de3-na
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents, ..., sealed documents, official, ... of the fields of Apisal and Gu’edina

sux: u3 musz-bi-an-na i3-gal2 mu {d}amar-{d}suen lugal-am3
en: and Mušbiana, are here; year: “Amar-Suen is king.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba nig2-ka9-ak kusz u3 kiszib3 dabx(U8)?-ba-bi lu2-{d}nam2-an-ka i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: accounts of leather and sealed documents of their dab, Lu-namanka, are here;

sux: mu {d}amar-{d}suen lugal
en: year: “Amar-Suen is king.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba im e2-tum sze gesz e3-a u3 nig2-ka9 didli i3-gal2 giri3 lu2-gi-na
en: Basket-of-tablets: tablets, ‘chambers,’ threshed barley, and acccounts, various, are here; via Lugina.

sux: pisan-dub-ba nig2-ka9-ak ur-{d}en-lil2-la2 nu-banda3-gu4 i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: accounts of Ur-Enlila, manager of oxen, are here;

sux: mu {d}amar-{d}suen lugal-e ur-bi2-lum{ki} mu-hul
en: year: “Amar-Suen, the king, Urbilum destroyed.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba {kusz}du10-gan sza3-bi su-ga lu2 nig2-dab5-ba-ke4-ne mu 5(disz)-kam i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: pouches, therefroms, restitiutions, of the men of nigdab, (a period of) 5 years; are here;

sux: mu us2-sa a-ra2 3(disz)-kam si-mu-ru-um{ki} ba-hul-ta mu {d}nanna kar-zi-da-sze3
en: from the year following: “For the 3rd time Simurum was destroyed” to the year: “Nanna of Karzida.”

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 la2-ia3 lugal-ukken-ne2 nu-banda3-gu4 i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: sealed documents, debts of Lugal-ukkene, manager of oxen, are here.

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 dabx(U8)-ba lugal-ku3-zu u3 lu2-du10-ga mu ha-ar-szi{ki} ki-masz{ki} ba-hul
en: Basket-of-tablets: xxx xxx xxx xxx

sux: pisan-dub-ba kiszib3 gaba#-ri lu2 nig2-dab5 e2 NE [x]-bi#-tum [x]-KU#
en: Basket-of-tablets: xxx xxx xxx

sux: [i3]-gal2#
en: xxx

sux: sa12!-du5 GAR dumu-zi!(GI)-da a mu-ru
en: (PN) the ... land recorder of Dumuzi, dedicated it (this vase).

sux: pisan-dub-ba szuku-ra ak dam-gar3 gar-ra-ke4-ne i3-gal2
en: Basket-of-tablets: xxx xxx xxx

sux: mu en {d}nanna masz-e i3-pa3
en: xxx

sux: er-s,e2-tum-mi er-s,e2-tum u2-li-id lu-ha-ma lu-hu-mu-u2 u2-li-id2 i-szi-na i-szi-nu-um u2-li-id szu-bu-ul-tam{am} szu-bu-ul-tum u2-li-id me-er-ha i-na-mi _a-sza3_ {d}en-lil2 mi-it-ha-ri-im _sze asza5{a-sza3}_ {d}suen i-s,e2-di
suxts: erṣetummi erṣetum ūlid luḫammâ luhummû ūlid išīna išīnum ūlid šubultam šubultum ūlid merḫa inami eqel ellil mitḫarim u’i eqlim sîn iṣṣedi
en: The earth, they say, the earth bore the mud; the mud bore the stalk; the stalk bore the spike; the spike bore the seed. They say in the field of Enlil, the square one, the barley of the field Sin was harvesting,

sux: {d}utu u-sza-ap-ha-ar a-na-mi _igi gurusz_ i-te-ru-ub me-er-hu-um ma-na lu-usz-pu-ur u3 lu-wa-'i3-ir a-na _dumu-munus_ an 7(disz@v) 7(disz@v) li-il-qe2-nim _{gesz#}gub_ sza sa-am-ti _dug_ sza hu-la-lim li-sa-ba-nim me tam!-tim el#-lu-tim me-er-ha li#-sze#-li-[a] [i]-na _igi gurusz_
suxts: šamaš ušapḫar anami īn eṭlim īterub merḫum manna lušpur u luwa’’ir ana marāt anim sebe sebe lilqênim manzāzam ša samti karpatam ša ḫulalim lisābānim mê tâmtim ellūtim merḫa lišēli'ā ina īn eṭlim
en: Šamaš was gathering together. They say into the eye of the man did enter the seed. Whom should I send and instruct to the daughters of An, 7-7? Let them take a stand of carneol, a pot of chalcedony; let them ladle out water of the sea, pure, the seed let them lift out from the eye of the man.

sux: igi musz-husz igi lu2-[ulu3] musz-husz igi lu2 nig2-hul-dim2#-ma musz-husz an-ne2 ba-te im szeg3-szeg3 ki-a ba-te {u2}szim nu-mu2-mu2 gu4-e ba-te {gesz}szudul5-bi im-du8 e2-tur3-e ba-te ga-ra-bi im-ta-kum-kum inim gar-ra ha-ba-an-dib-dib gurusz-ra mu-na-te ib2-la2 mu-da-an-gaz sikil-ra mu-na-te tug2 mu-da-an-szub um-me-da dumu-da mu-na-te lirum-bi mu-e-du8 |SAR.SAR|-e ba-te i-iz za3-hi-li im-hul pu2 {gesz}kiri6 ba-te gurun im-hul igi kur-ra kur-ta nam-ta-an-e3 szeg9-bar-re si-musz-bi nam-ta-an-e3 igi hul igi gig-ga he2-tar {kusz}a-ga2-la2-gin7 he2-dar {dug}sila3-bur-zi bahar2-ka tilla2-a he2-gaz-gaz gub-bu-da-ba gub-bu-da-ba ka e-sir2-ra-ka gub-bu-da-ba szul dingir nu-tuku gaba im-ma-an-ri
en: The dragon-face (is) the dragon-face of a man, the dragon-face of a man causing evil approached heaven (and) the clouds bring (no) rain. He approached the earth, and the plants do not grow. He approached the ox, and its yoke does not open. He approached the stall and smashes its cheese-pot. Utterances have passed by. He approached the lad and sapped his (sexual) energies, he approached the maiden and tossed away her towel. He approached the nurse with the child - her arms were torn apart. He approached the vegetables - lettuce and cress became bad. He approached the garden, the fruit became bad. The eye of the mountain came out from the mountain, The wild ram let its shining horns come out. May the evil eye (like?) the sick eye be cut off. May it split open like a leather bag. May it go to pieces (like) the potter's bur-zi-pot on the market place. While standing, while standing, while standing at the mouth? of the street, it opposes the young man who has no personal god.

en: Goddess of the fearsome divine powers, clad in terror, riding on the great divine powers, inanna, made perfect by the holy a-an-kar weapon, drenched in blood, rushing around in great battles, with shield resting on the ground (?), covered in storm and flood, great lady inanna, knowing well how to plan conflicts, you destroy mighty lands with arrow and strength and overpower lands. In heaven and on earth you roar like a lion and devastate the people. Like a huge wild bull you triumph over lands which are hostile. Like a fearsome lion you pacify the insubordinate and unsubmissive with your gall. My lady, on your acquiring the stature of heaven, maiden inanna, on your becoming as magnificent as the earth, on your coming forth like Utu the king and stretching your arms wide, on your walking in heaven and wearing fearsome terror, on your wearing daylight and brilliance on earth, on your walking in the mountain ranges and bringing forth beaming rays, on your bathing the girin plants of the mountains (in light),

The lady of battle, the great child of Suen, maiden inanna, I shall praise. (inanna announced:) "When I, the goddess, was walking around in heaven, walking around on earth, when I, inanna, was walking around in heaven, walking around on earth, when I was walking around in Elam and Subir, when I was walking around in the Lulubi mountains, when I turned towards the centre of the mountains, as I, the goddess, approached the mountain it showed me no respect, as I, inanna, approached the mountain it showed me no respect, as I approached the mountain range of Ebih it showed me no respect." "Since they did not act appropriately on their own initiative, since they did not put their noses to the ground for me, since they did not rub their lips in the dust for me,

en: May the mountain observe (?) my conduct. May Ebih give me honour and praise me." inanna, the child of Suen, put on the garment of royalty and girded herself in joy. She bedecked her forehead with terror and fearsome radiance. She arranged cornelian rosettes around her holy throat. She brandished the seven-headed szita weapon vigorously to her right and placed straps of lapis lazuli on her feet. At dusk she came forth regally and stood in the street at the Gate of Wonder. She made an offering to An and addressed a prayer to him. An, in delight at inanna, stepped forward and took his place. He filled the seat of honour of heaven. (inanna announced:) "An, my father, I greet you! Lend your ear to my words. An has made me terrifying throughout heaven. Owing to you my word has no rival in heaven or on earth. At the limits of heaven are the silig weapon, the antibal and mansium emblems."

en: Shepherd, named by pure An, for whome he (An) determined a great destiny in the heavens, Rim-Sin, named by pure An, for whome he (An) determined a great destiny in the heavens, Noble one, from the true womb he was fit for kingship. You are the one who was magnanimously selected for the lordship over all the people. In Larsa, the...mountain, where the rites of nobility were libated, You were truly chosen to be the shepherd over Sumer and Akkad. Great An, who is magnificent in the heavens and the earth, lord who is wise in everything, Father of the gods who looks at this place to determine the destinies, Whose utterance in important, and whose commands never cease, Who...in the midst of the sanctified heavens, O noble one, Rim-Sin, you were teh shepherd ever since you came forth from the womb, Therefore great An made his loving heart manifest for you. Because of your justice he shall truly choose you, In the midst of the remote heavens he shall make your days of life surpassing (in number), Kingship over the wide mountain-land for the days to come he shall give to you. With his!? sanctified command he shall determine a destiny of life for you, With a decree that nothing can change he shall add a long life for you, The sanctified crown he shall make firm on your head, On the throne of life he shall seat you grandly, The scepter of justice he shall place in your hand, The enkara-weapon that makes the lands firm he shall gird to your body. The scepter over the numerous people he shall coner upon you. He shall open for you the teats of the shining heavens so that the rain of heavens shall rain for you. Years of propserity and days of abundance he shall give to you from the midst of the heavens. Months of splendor and a joyful heart he shall establish for your (life)time.

The [...]of life of the magnificent city-gate [...] may they open for you. May the protective gods, guardians of the magnificent city-gate, Rejoice at your sight, May their faces brighten. ... The city-gate of Ur, the city-gate of splendor, When you entered it [...] [...] the brickwork of Ur, [...] the city-gate of Ur,

en: In the [...] of the magnificent city-gate of Ur May they... In the [...] magnificent city-gate of Ur May they speak on your behalf. [...] and joy of heart may they establish for you. May favourable [signs] and words that please the heart Be placed before you. May they direct your path to a pure place, a place of life. Rim-Sin, foremost prince of the mountains and the land (Sumer), In the Dubarabalmah, the Foundation or Ur, In the Dubarabalmah, Nigerimszutabbi, In the Dubarabalmah, Nigerimszu'urur In the Dubarabalmah, Duggabszugigi, In the Dubarabalmah, Duggabszutabbi, When the guardian deities of the magnificent city-gate Greet the entering gods, At your right and at your left, for a destiny of life, Forever, may they stand. Your prayer to Nanna and Ningal May they convey. To never let the good signs leave your side, May they (Nanna and Ningal?) have your finest offerings. O Rim-Sin, my king! It is a [prayer of the benevolent gods?] entering the magnificent city-gate.

en: Rim-Sin, king of the august rites, leader of the assembly, who is foremost in the numerous rites of nobility, In the abzu, the pure and magnificent shrine of the Ekisznugal, Great magnificence on the inside and on the outside, In the foundation of teh house with the purified and sanctified interior, The sweet smell, like a forest of aromatic woods from cedars and haszur-trees, The temple, its pedestal, in the interior of the temple, The umbrella for the temple, the aura of the temple, In the great corner, the pure corner, in the firm interior, The plan of his gate, On the door ornament a sun-disz, its top... To its right and left there is a bison,... The god is guarding his gate. With magnificent kiszkanu-wood he makes this place beautiful for you. The threshold of the..., the bolt, the doorsill, the threshold, the door, the bolt, the bar of the temple, The supporting wall of the temple terrasse, the foundation of the hosues, in the purified and sanctified interior, These pure...-reeds like gold and silver, At the side of the reed-marsh in the absu of the Ekisznugal, In the pure shrine, where the cows roam around, In order to seize...as presents, ... ...

en: The reed shoot of the old reed, the pastures... Lying on..., the prepared reed... ..., the foundation,... In the middle of the swamps, the abzu of the Ekisznugal, In the pure swamp, the reed-marsh with pure water...may they grow for you. The interior of the temple, the gate of the great and magnificent shrine, The true woman, who is full of awe, who is perfect, who is foremost in augustness, Who multiplies fertility, and allows it to ripen like fruit, Who is full of awe, who is praised, whose aura is perfect like that of a mountain range, In the inside, on the outside, the four corners of the world, The statue, its ornament, the magnificent protective spirit of the temple, In order to change the middle of the month, The guardian of the temple, the protective spirit of the temple, The angubbu-priestess, the child of the temple, From the base of the surrounding wall, the guardian of the outer gate, the footstool of the gods, They sweep the floor of the residence for you for the magnificent rites and hand-washing rites of the temple, The..., its base, the magnificent protective spirit of the temple, They bring butter and milk, and breads for you, so be it. Thus the angubbu-priestess, the protective spirit, the Amasaga ("beautiful mother") who is agreeable in the temple, May (they) receive your finest offerings. When you light the wood in the incence-bowl, May Nanna and Ningal accept it, With their pure words may they pray for you. O Rim-Sin, my king. 46 lines

en: When you prepare the pure food offering, When your pure hand touches the pure and the sanctified offerings, When you touch the sacrifices, When you articulate what you say from the heart, When you pay respect, when you lift your pure hand (in prayer), May Nanna, the king of heavens and earth, the lord, your good protective spirit, agree. May Ningal, the magnificent lady, your lady of good omens, agree. For the king, Nanna and Ningal, the great gods, relieving the famine,  For you, Rim-Sin, the king, (they) filled the temples of the gods with abundance. The king who was named by Enlil, whose reign has a destiny of abundance. Days of abundance, years of splendor, May a destiny of...and a destiny of abundance be your destiny. O king, to never let abundance cease, day and night, all through the night, The days pass for you, they are good for you, they are stable for you. O king, at first you heaped up in heaps your food offerings in the middle of the abzu, O king, afterwards <you heaped up in heaps> your food offerings in the great courtyard. In order to let abundance never end, O king, the temple(-district?) prepares abundance for you.  O Rim-Sin, king of Ur, who restored the magnificent rites of the Ki'ur:  May Nanna, king of heavens and earth, firmly place on your head the true, magnificent crown that makes kingship perfect. Ningal, your magnificent queen, who brought relief from famine, Having made life good for the future with her agreeable heart, May she...your life. With her pure hand..the great aura of kingship,

en: may she give the magnificent scepter of heavens and earth into your hand like the Me-garment. O Rim-Sin, king of the Ki'ur who...abundance, To never let constance attendance cease, O king, may the Tigris bring abundance for you. May the Idnum...to his satisfaction be filled with everlasting water. May the Idnun, the true nun-canal, life of the land, Bring fish and fowl for you. From the sea, the remote sea, from the water reservoirs, May they bring creation that shall never end to your king. In the wide steppe andt eh wide places the quadrupeds and the living creatures... May the dikes and small canals in the fields raise their (water levels) for you. May they establish life for you. May they establish prayers and a favourable omen for you. May they establish pleasure for you. May they establish favourable signs for you. May they please your heart. May they please your body. May they make your outer form and your true omen good for you. May the hearts of Nanna and Ningal bring favourable signs and a destiny of life forever. Rim-Sin, the king who holds the ritually appropriate (things) and abundance for the great gods. May the country be stable for him, may the foundation of the country be firm for him. May Nanna, king of heavens and earth, let the land agree with you marvelously. O Rim-Sin, my king. 51 (lines)

en: Because of this Lord Nunamnir was happy, his liver surged with joy. For the daughter of Sîn, the heir of his close brother, he determined a destiny. Princess Ištar, just as heaven has been given to you as a gift, so has the earth ... Lady, that wide earth which creates everything, the earth has been ... When you bring ... near to the broad mountains like a snake, may you set your foot upon it. Extend a net over all the (various) mountains, lands and seas, ... ... may they ..., ... may they make obeisances to you. ... taking the sanctuary. When she makes the tops of the high terraces and daises tower high, ... heaven and earth cannot bear your overbearing attitude. They tremble before the ... of the violent storms.

en: ... making obeisances and invoking the name, ... and whose goddess has become soured/jealous towards him, as long as he does not seek out ..., no god will be agreeable to his petition. ... (the mountain of Sumer and) Akkad, the shade of the world quarters, ... the foundation of all constructed settlements, (at my royal dais,) reposing (like a horned bull ...,) at my temple Nippur, the shrine of Enlil-ship, the mainstay of the nation, the sanctuary, the relaxing dwelling place, which is called by my name, may your ladyship be also manifested in that place, ... The good protective spirit, (my) eloquent god who is standing in front of me, the craftsman of the centerpoint of the Ekur temple, discoverer of advice and planning, the finest oil, may he be your guardian, he against whom your wrath was great and whom your divine fury has overcome. May wise Nin-imma-imma cool your heart with pleasant conversations. Lady, I have established for you my weighty commands, divine powers that cannot be demanded by anyone (else); (and) like me, may Ea, king of the Apsu, treat you well.

akk: a-na be-li2-ia qi2-[bi2]-ma um-ma {munus}szi#-ib#-tu _geme2_-ka-a-ma# _e2-gal_-lum# sza-lim {disz}i3-[li2-ha]-az#-na-a-ia {lu2}as#-si2#-in#-num# sza an-[nu-ni-tim il]-li-kam# i-na li#-[ib-bi _e2_ an-nu-ni-tim] [...]-x-ma [...] babila#{ki} [a-na be-li2-ia isz]-ta#-ap-ra-szu [... ha-am-mu]-ra#-pi2 [...]-ku
akkts: ana bēliya qibima umma šibtu amatkama ekallum šalim ilī-ḫaznaya assinnum ša annunītim illikam ina libbi bīt annunītim ... ... babilim ana bēliya ištapraššu ... ḫammurapi ...
en: To my lord speak! Thus Šibtu, your maid: The palace is well. Ilī-Ḫaznaya, the assinnum of Annunītum, came to me. in the middle of the house of Annunītum ..., and ... of Babylon to my lord he has sent him, ... Ḫammurapi ...

akk: [asz-szu-um t,e4]-em# babila#[{ki}] it#-ta#-tim# asz-qi2 asz2-ta-al-ma# _lu2_ szu-u2 ma-da-tim a-na ma-a-tim an-ni-tim u2-sza-am u2-ul i-ka-asz-sza-ad be-li2 i-im-ma-ar sza _dingir_-lum _lu2_ sza-a-ti i-ip-pe2-szu ta-ka-asz-sza-as-su2 u3 e-li-szu ta-az-za-az _u4_-mu-szu qe2-er-bu u2-ul i-ba-al-lu-ut, be-li2 an-ni-tam lu-u2 i-de# la-ma t,e4-em i3-li2-ha-az-na-a-ia# sza an-nu-ni-tum isz-pu-ra-asz-szu# _u4 5(disz)-kam_ a-na-ku asz2-ta-a-al#-ma# [t,e4]-mu-um sza an-nu-ni-[tum] [isz]-pu#-ra-ak-kum u3 sza a-sza-lu isz-ti-in-ma
akkts: aššum ṭēm babilim ittātim ašqi aštālma awīlum šū madātim ana mātim annītim ušām ul ikaššad bēlī immar ša īlum awīlam šâti ippešu takaššassu u elišu tazzaz ūmuššu qerbu ul iballuṭ bēlī annītam lū idē lama ṭēm ilī-ḫaznaya ša annunītum išpuraššu ūmam ḫamšam anāku aštālma ṭēmum ša annunītum išpurakkum u ša ašālu ištīnma
en: Concerning the report about Babylon, signs to drink I gave. I asked, and that man many things against this country thinks up. He will not succeed. My lord will see what the god to that man will do. You will capture him. Further, over him you will stand. In his day that is near, he will not live. May my lord know this! Before (the arrival of) the message of Ilī-Ḫaznaya with which Annunītum sent him, the 5th day, I myself asked, and the message that Annunītum sent to you and (the answer to) what I asked are the same.

akk: a-na be-li2-ia qi2-bi2-ma um-ma {munus}szi-ib-tu geme2-ka-a-ma _e2-gal_-lum sza-lim i-na _e2_ an-nu-ni-tim _u4 3(disz)-kam_ {disz}sze-le-bu-um im-ma-hu um-ma an-nu-ni-tum-ma {disz}zi-im-ri-li-im i-na ba-ar-tim i-la-at-ta-ku-ka pa-ga-ar-ka u2-s,u2-ur _ARAD2-mesz_ eb-bi-ka sza ta-ra-am-mu <i-na> i-ta-ti-ka# szu-ku-un
akkts: ana bēliya qibima umma šibtu amatkama ekallum šalim ina bīt annunītim umam šalšam šēlebum immaḫu umma annunītumma zimrī-lim, ina bārtim ilattakūka pagarka uṣur wardī ebbika ša tarammû ina itātika šukun
en: To my lord, speak! Thus Šibtu, your maid: The palace is well. In the house of Annunītum on the 3rd day Fox went into a trance, thus Annunītum: “Zimri-Lim, in rebellion they will test you. Your body guard! Servants of your ‘purity,’ whom you love, at your sides place!

akk: szu-zi-is-su2-nu-ti-ma li-is,-s,u2-ru-ka# a-na ra-ma-ni-ka#-[ma] la ta-at-ta-na-al#-[la]-ak# u3 _lu2-mesz_ sza i-la-at#-[ta-ku]-ka# a-na qa-ti-ka a-[wi-li-_mesz_] szu-nu-ti u2-ma-al-[la-am] i-na-an-na a-[nu-um-ma] sza-ar#-ta-[am u3 si2-si2-ik-tam] sza as-si2-[in-nim] a-na s,e#-[er be-li2-ia] u2-sza-bi-[lam]
akkts: šuzissunūtima liṣṣurūka ana ramānikama lā tattanallak u awīlū ša ilattakūka ana qātika awīlī šunūti umallâm inanna anumma šartam u sissiktam ša assinnim ana ṣēr beliya ušābilam
en: Let them stand (before you), that they protect you! By yourself do not keep going around! The men who will test you— into your hand those men I will fill.” Now then, hair and hem of the assinnum to my lord I have sent.

akk: a-na be-li2-ia qi2-bi2-ma um-ma {munus}szi-ib-tu _geme2_-ka-a-ma i-na _e2_ an-nu-ni-tim sza li-ib-bi a-lim {disz}{munus}a-ha-tum _munus-tur_ {d}da-gan-ma-lik im-ma-hi-ma ki-a-am iq-bi um-ma-mi zi-im-ri-li-im u3 szum-ma at-ta mi-sza-ta-an-ni a-na-ku e-li-ka a-ha-ab-bu-us,4 na-ak-ri-ka a-na qa-ti-ka
akkts: ana bēliya qibima umma šibtu amatkama ina bītim annunītim ša libbi alim aḫātum ṣuḫarat dagan-mālik immaḫima kiam iqbi ummāmi zimri-lim u šumma atta mišātanni anāku elika aḫabbuṣ nakrīka ana qātika
en: To my lord speak! Thus Šibtu, your maid: In the Annunītum-house of the center of the city Aḫātum, daughter of Dagan-Mālik, went into a trance and in the following way spoke, thus: “Zimri-Lim, and if you disregard me, I myself over you am bursting (with love); your enemies in your hand

akk: u2-ma-al-la u3 _lu2-mesz_ szar-ra-qi2-ia a-s,a-ab-ba-at-ma a-na ka-ra-asz {d}nin-e2-gal-lim a-ka-am-mi-is-su2-nu-ti i-na sza-ni-i-im u4-mi-im {disz}a-hu-um _lu2-sanga_ t,e4-ma-am an-ne2-e-em szar-ta-am u3 si2-is-si2-ik-tam ub-la-am-ma a-na be-li2-ia asz-pu-ra-am szar-ta-am u3 si2#-is#-si2-ik-tam ak-nu-ka-am-ma a-na s,e-er be-li2-ia usz-ta-bi-lam
akkts: umalla u awīlī šarrāqīya aṣabbatma ana karāš bēlet-ekallim akammissunūti ina šanîm ūmim aḫum šangûm ṭēmam annêm šārtam u sissiktam ublamma ana bēliya ašpuram šārtam u sissiktam aknukamma ana ṣēr beliya uštābilam
en: I will fill; further, the men, my robbbers I will seize, and in the camp of Bēlet-ekallim I will collect them. The next day, Aḫum, the temple administrator, this report, a lock of hair and a hem brought to me, and to my lord I wrote. Lock of hair and hem I sealed, and to my lord I have sent.

akk: [a-na be-li2-ia] [qi2-bi2]-ma# um#-ma {munus}szi-ib-tu _geme2_-ka-a-[ma] _e2 dingir-mesz-dingir-mesz e2-gal_-lum u3 ne-pa-ra-tum sza-al-ma sza-ni-tam {munus}ka-ak-ka-li-di i-na _e2_ {d}i-tur2-me-er i-mu-ur um-ma-a-mi _2(disz) {gesz}ma2_ ma-al-lu-u2 ra-ab-bu-tum na-ra-am pa-ar-ku-ma _lugal_ u3 _lu2-mesz_ re-du-um _sza3-ba_ ra-ki-ib sza i-mi-it-tim [a]-na# szu-me2-lim [i]-sza-as-su-u2 [um]-ma szu-nu-ma szar-ru-tum [ha]-at,#-t,u2-um _{gesz}gu-za_
akkts: ana bēliya qibima umma šibtu amatkama bīt ilī ekallum u nepārātum šalmā šanītam kakka-lidi ina bīt itur-mer īmur ummāmi šinā eleppātum mallû rabbûtum nāram parkūma šarrum u awīlū rēdûm libbum rakib ša imittim ana šumēlim išassû umma šūnuma šarrūtum ḫaṭṭum kussûm
en: To my lord speak! Thus Šibtu, your maid: the temples, the palace, and the workhouses are well. Another thing: Kakka-Lidi in the temple of Itur-Mer saw (a vision); thus (her): “Two barge-rafts, large ones, the river were blocking, and the king and soldiers within were riding. Those on the right to the ones on the left were shouting, thus they: “Kingship, sceptre, throne,

akk: pa-lu-um ma-tum e-li-tum u3 sza-ap-li-tum a-na zi-im-ri-li-im na-ad#-na-at# u3 _lu2-mesz_ re-du-u2-um ka-lu-szu# [i]-ip-pa-al a-na zi-im-ri-li-im-ma na-ad-na-at _{gesz}ma2_ ma#-al#-lu-u2 szu-nu a-na ba#-ab _e2-gal_-lim [...]-ma [...]-szu
akkts: palûm mātum elītum u šaplītum ana zimri-lim nadnat u awīlū rēdûm kalûšu ippal ana zimri-limma nadnat eleppātum mallû šūnu ana bāb ekallim ...-ma ...-šu
en: reign, land upper and lower to Zimri-Lim are given!”; further, the soldiers, all of them, were answering: “To Zimri-Lim it is given!” these barge-rafts to the gate of the palace ... ... ”

akk: a-na be-li2-[ia] qi2#-bi2-ma um-ma {munus}szi-ib-tu _geme2_-ka-a-ma _e2-gal_-lum sza-lim _e2-hi-a dingir-mesz_ u3 ne-pa-ra-tum sza#-al-mu# [a]-di# re-esz wa-ar-hi-im [te]-re-tim a-na szu-lum be-li2-ia [u2]-sze#-pi2#-isz#-ma te-re#-[tum sza] szu-lum be-li2-ia sza#-al#-ma i-na s,e-e-tim be-li2 pa-ga-ar-szu
akkts: ana bēliya qibima umma šibtu amatkama ekallum šalim bīti ilī u neparātum šalmū adi rēš warhim têrētim ana šulum bēliya ušēpišma têrētum ša šulum bēliya šalmā ina ṣētim bēlī pagaršu
en: To my lord speak! Thus Šibtu, your servant. The palace is well. The temples and workshops are well. At the beginning of the month extispicies for the wellbeing of my lord I caused to have done, and the extispicy (reports) for the wellbeing of my lord are propitious. From the heat, my lord, his body

akk: li-is,-s,u2-ur i-tu-u2-um sza-ki-in sza pi2-i i-li-i-im be-li2 li-pu-usz2 u3 a-iu-um-ma i-na _lugal-mesz_ sza it-ti be-li2-ia i-sza-ri-isz i-da-ab-bu-ub i-na bi-bi-il-tim-ma it-ti be-li2-ia i-da-ab-bu-ub#
akkts: liṣṣur ittum šakin sza pī ilim bēlī līpuš u ayumma ina šarrī sza itti bēliya išāriš idabbub ina bibiltimma itti bēliya idabbub
en: may he guard. The ominous sign is established. According to the mouth of the gods my lord, may he do. And whoever among the kings with my lord straight speaks, in the carrying with my lord, he will speak.

akk: a-na {munus}szi-ib-tu qi2-bi2-ma um-ma be-el-ki-ma asz-szum sza ki-a-am ta-asz-pu-ri-im um-ma at-ti-ma i-na ba-ru-u2-tim sza _{gesz}tukul-mesz_ a-na-ku et-me2-ku sza ta-asz-pu-ri-im i-na ba-ru-u2-tim-ma sza _{gesz}tukul-mesz_ et-me2-e-ti am-mi-nim i-na ba-ru-ut s,a-ba-at _iri#{ki}_ la et-me2-e-ti#
akkts: ana šibtu qibima umma bēlkima aššum ša kiam tašpurīm umma attima ina bārûtim ša kakkī anāku etmêku ša tašpurīm ina bārûtimma ša kakkī etmêti ammīnim ina bārût ṣabāt ālim lā etmêti
en: To Sibtu speak! Thus your lord: As to what you in the following way wrote me, thus you: In the divination of weapons I am occupied.” In that which you wrote me, in the very divination of weapons, you are occupied? Why in the divination of the siezing of the city are you not occupied?

akk: u3 ki-a-am u2-ul ta-asz-pu-ri-im# um-ma at-ti-ma _iri{ki}_ szu-u2 is,-s,a-ab-ba-at u2-lu-ma u2-ul is,-s,a-ab-ba-at asz-szum ar-hi-isz# ka-sza-di-ia sza ta-asz-pu-ri#-im ar-hi-isz a-na _siskur2-re_ isz8-tar2 a-ka-asz-sza-dam
akkts: ū kiam ul tašpurīm umma attima ālum šu iṣṣabbat ūlūma ul iṣṣabbat aššum arḫiš kašādiya ša tašpurīm arḫiš ana nīqi ištar akaššadam
en: Further, in the following way you did not write me, thus you: “That city will be siezed,” or rather, “will not be siezed.” As to my quick arrival, about which you wrote me, quickly for the sacrifice of Ištar I will arrive.

akk: a-na be-li2-ia qi2-bi2-ma# um-ma ia-qi2-im-{d}iszkur _ARAD2_-ka-a-ma be-li2 ki-a-am isz-pu-ra-am um-ma-a-mi s,a-bu-um _babila_{ki} sza i-na sa-ga-ra-tim{ki} wa-szi-ib i-na sa-ga-ra-tim#{ki} s,i2-di-tam li-im-hu-ur u3 sza [i]-na  _bad3_{ki}-ia-ah-du-li-im wa-szi-ib# i-na _bad3_{ki}-ia#-ah-du-li-im-ma s,i2#-[di]-tam# szu-um-hi-ir-ma# s,a-ba-am sze-tu [u3 s,a]-ba#-am sza tu-sza-at,-t,e4-ru [t,u2-ur]-dam _ud_ 5(disz) _kam_ pa-an mu-szi-im tup-pi2 be-li2-ia [ik-szu]-dam# la#-ma# tup-pi2 be-li2-ia i-ka-asz-sza-dam [x x x tup?-pi2? ni]-id#-na-at-{d}suen [... s,a-bu-um] _babila#_{ki} [...] tup-pi2 be-li2-ia
en: Say to my lord, thus Yaqim-Addu your servant: My lord wrote thus: 'Let the Babylonian army that is stationed at Sagaratum receive provisions in Sagaratum and have the one that is stationed at Dur-Yahdu-Lim receive provisions at Dur-Yahdu-Lim. Send that army and the army that you have registered.' The tablet of my lord arrived on the 5th day before nightfall. Before the tablet of my lord arrived, ... [the tablet?] of Nidnat-Sin... ... [the army?] of Babylon [...] my lord's tablet.

akk: [...] x-u2 i-na# pu-lu-uh-ti be-li2-ia [u2-sza]-asz2#-t,i2-ir i-na tup-pi2 te-<bi>-ib-ti ha#-al-s,i-im sza a-na s,e-er be-li2-ia u2-sza-bi-lam hi-im-mu-um sza-t,e4-er i-na#-an-na szum-ma i-in be-li2-ia ma-hi-ir [be-li2] li-isz-ta-al-ma  _lu2-szu-gi_  u3 _lu2-tur-mesz_ sza  _kaskal_ a-la-kam la i-le-u2 lu-u2 lu-bi-ir-ma a-na ma-as,-s,a-ar-ti _dur3_{ki} u2-lu-ma a-szar be-li2 i-qa-ab-bu-u2 li-si-qu2!(BA)-szu-nu-ti u3 s,a-ba-am be2-eh-ra-am lu-bi-ra-am-ma ki-ma na-asz-pa-ar-ti be-li2-ia lu-ut,-ru-dam an-ni-tam la an-ni-tam be-li2 li-isz-pu-ra-am u3 as-su2-ur-ri be-li2 ki-a-am i-qa-ab-bi# um#-ma-a-mi s,a-bu-um _babila_{ki} i-zi-iz ki-ma _lu2-mesz_ tap-pi2-szu i-na e-s,e2-di-im u2-ne-eh mi-im-ma s,a-bu-um szu-u2 [u2]-ul i-s,i2-id i-na sza-ni-im
en: ...because of fear of my lord I had it written. In my lord's registration tablet for the district which I sent back to him, a 'himmum' is written. Now if it pleases my lord, let him consider if I should assign the old men and the young ones who cannot go on the campaign to guard the wall or the place my lord my lord orders, and choosing the elite army send them to my lord as per his instructions. Let my lord write to me whether this should be so. Perhaps my lord will say: 'The Babylonian army will be upset.' Like their compatriots, I have exempted them from service. That army has not been gathered.

akk: u4-mi-im sza a-na sa-ga-ra-tim{ki} ik-szu-du-nim tup-pi2 ni-id-na-at-{d}suen# ik-szu-dam-ma ip-t,u2-ru-nim#?
en: Following the day that they arrive in Sagaratum and the tablet of Nidnat-Sin comes to me, they will be released.

akk: a-na be-li2-ia qi2-bi2-ma um-ma la-u2-um _ARAD2_-ka-a-ma {disz}as3-qu2-du-um _masz2-szu-gid2-gid2_ isz-tu ma-ha-ar _lugal_ il-li-ka-am a-szar id-bu-bu ma-da-tim-ma id-bu-ub [a-na] a-ia-szi-im iq-bu-nim [ka]-ar#-s,i2-ia [ka-ar-s,i2] {d}suen-i-di2-nam
akkts: ana bēliya qibima umma la’um waradkama asqudum bārûm ištu maḫar šarrim illikām ašar idbubu madātimma idbub ana ayyâšim iqbûnim karṣīya karṣī sîn-iddinam
en: To my lord speak! thus La’um, your servant: Asqudum, the diviner, from before the king came to me. Where he talked, many things he talked. To me they said so. Slander of me, slander of Sîn-Iddinam

akk: [u3 {d}]utu#-illat-su2 [i-na] _igi lugal_ i-ku-ul ma#-am-ma-an i-na qa-ti-szu u2-ul sza-lim a-na s,e-er# be-li2-ia a-ka-asz-sza-da-am-ma t,e4-ma-am ga-am-ra-am ma-ha-ar be-li2-ia a-sza-ka-an
akkts: u šamaš-illassu ina pān šarrim īkul mamman ina qātišu ul šalim ana ṣēr bēliya akaššadamma ṭēmam gamram maḫar bēliya ašakkan
en: and of Šamaš-Illassu before the king he ‘ate.’ No one in his hand is safe. To my lord I will arrive, and a full report before my lord I will place.

akk: a-na as3-qu2-du-um qi2-bi2-ma um-ma ba-nu-um-ma t,up-pa-ti-ka sza tu-sza-bi-lam# esz15-me2 ki-a-am ta-asz-pu-ra-[am] um-ma at-ta-a-[ma] te-re!-tim a-na szu-lum ha#-[al-s,i2-im?] e-pu-usz2-ma te-re-tu#-[ia la-ap-ta] _giri3? lu2_ na-ak-ri-im sza#-[ki-in ...] u3 te-re-tim a-na ter#-[qa{ki}] sa-ga-ra-tim u3 bad3{ki#}-[ia-ah-du]-li#-im sza _u4 mu-kam u2-lu _iti# [u4 6(disz)]-kam#_ szu-pi2-isz ak-ki-ma na-asz-pa-ar-ti-ka te-re-tim u2-sze-pi2-isz _sila4-hi-a_ sza ta-asz-pu-ra-am
akkts: ana asqudum qibima umma bannumma ṭuppātika ša tušābilam ešme kīam tašpuram umma attama têrētim ana šulum ḫalṣim epušma têrētūya šalmā laptā šepi awīl nakrim šakin ... u têrētim ana terqa saggaratim u dūr-iaḫdu-lim ša ūmī šattim ūlū šeššet warḫī šūpîš akkima našpartika têrētim ušepiš puḫādū ša tašpuram
en: To Gerbil speak! Thus Bannum: “Your tablets you had sent here I heard. As follows you wrote me, thus you: ‘The extispicies for the well-being of the district I performed, and my extispicies were unfavorable; the foot(print) of an enemy was placed ..., and extispicies for Terqa, Saggaratum and Dūr-Yaḫdun-Lim for the days of a year or of 6 months have done.’ According to your letter extispicies I had performed. The lambs, about which you wrote me,

akk: wa-ar-ki t,up-pi2-ia an-ni-im a-na _u4 3(disz)-kam_ i-ka-sza-du#-ni#-kum sza-ni-tam asz-szum _e2_-ka sza ta-asz-pu-ra-am i-na# pa#-ni-tim-ma ki-a-am ta-aq-be2-em um-ma at-ta-a-ma _2(disz) e2_-tim as,-ba-at _1(disz) e2_ da-am-qa-am# a-s,a-ba-at-ma _1(disz) e2_ u2-wa-asz-sza-ar# an-ni-tam ta-aq-be2-em i-na-an-na _e2_-tam sza i-in-ka# ma-ah-ru tu-usz2-sza-ab ma-am-ma-an a-na _e2_-ka u2-ul i-t,e4-eh-he
akkts: warki ṭuppiya annîm ana ūmim šalšim ikaššadūnikkum šanītam aššum bītika ša tašpuram ina panītimma kiam taqbêm umma attama šinā bītātim aṣbat išten bītam damqam aṣabbatma išten bītam uwaššar annītam taqbêm inanna bītam ša īnka maḫru tuššab mamman ana bītika ul iṭeḫḫe
en: after this my tablet, on the 3rd day, will reach you. Another thing: because of your house about which you wrote me, a while back, as follows you spoke to me, thus you: ‘2 houses I seized, 1 good house, I am keeping (lit. seizing) and 1 house I will release.’ This you said to me. Now (in) the house that your eye favors you will dwell; nobody your house will approach.

akk: a-na be-li2-ia qi2-bi2-ma um-ma isz-hi-{d}iszkur _ARAD2_-ka-a-ma _sila4 masz2-szu-gid2-gid2_ sza ma-ha-ar _dingir_ ik-bu-bu te-er-ta-szu a-mu-ur# i-na te-er-tim sza-a-ti na-[ap-la-as3-tu-um] i-na qa-qar ki-it-tim [sza-ki-in] pa-da-nu sza-ki-in-ma [...] pu-uz-rum da-na-na-am u2-ul# [i-szu] _ka2 e2-gal_-lim sza-lim
akkts: ana bēliya qibima umma išḫi-addu waradkama puḫād bārîm ša maḫar ilim ikbubu têrtašu amur ina têrtim šâti naplastum ina qaqqarim kīttim šakin padānu šakimma puzrum danānam ul īšu bāb ekallim šalim
en: To my lord speak! Thus Išḫi-Addu your servant: the sheep of the diviner which before the god he burned, his extispicy I saw; In that extispicy the ‛blinder’ at the ‛true spot’ was situated. The path was situated, and ... the mystery did not have the strength. The gate of the palace is well.

akk: i-na ma-as,-ra-ah _sipa_ {gesz}tukul sza-ki-in-ma _sipa_ ir-de#-[em] isz-da-an _sipa_ i-mi-it-[ta-am] sa3-ar-ma szu-me-lam na-as-[ha] da-an-na#-[at] szu#-me-lim sa3-ak-ki?-[isz] pa-at,-[ra]-at i-mi-it-ti# [u2]-ba-nim ta-ar#-[ka-at] szu-me-el2 u2-ba#-nim# ra#-ki#-[is] s,i2-ib-tum ma-ak#-[...] ha-szu-u2 sza-al#-[ma ...] ki-is,-rum i-mi#-[it-tam ...] e-le-tum sza#-[al-ma]
akkts: ina maṣraḫ rē’îm kakkum šakimma išdān rē’îm imittam sarmā šumēlam nasḫā dannat šumēlim sakkiš paṭrat imitti ubānim tarkat šumēl ubānim rakis ṣibtum mak-... hašû šalmā kiṣrum imittam ... elêtum šalmā
en: In the duct of the shepherd a weapon-mark, and the shepherd followed it; the two bases of the shepherd, to the right, were sectioned, on the left torn out. The fortress on the left like a s. was loose; The right of the finger was dark; the left of the finger was bound; the attachment was ...; the lungs were well; The knot to the right ... The upper parts were well.

sux: igi musz-husz igi lu2-ulu3 musz-husz igi lu2 nig2-hul-dim2-ma musz-husz an-e ba-te im nu-szeg3-szeg3 ki ba-te {u2}szim nu-mu2-mu2 gu4-de3 ba-te {gesz}szudulx(UR)-bi im-du8 e2-tur3-re ba-te ga-ra-bi im-gaz-gaz amasz-e ba-te uax(|NINDA2xMASZ2|) im-hul gurusz-ra ba-te usu lirum mu-da-an-kar ki-sikil-ra ba-te tug2 mu-da-an-szub um-me-da dumu-da mu-na-te ul3-la2 mu-da-si-il {d}asar-lu2-hi-e igi im-ma-an-sum nig2-i3-zu-a-mu u3 za-e in-ga-e-zu 7(disz)-a sze-ar3-re egir {gesz}naga3-kam 7(disz)-a sze-ar3-re egir na4-ar3-kam i3-ta u3-me-ni-hi kusz!-ta u3-me-ni-kesz2 nam-szub eridu{ki} gu2 lu2-tu!-ra u3-mu-ni-la2 {d}nin-tin-ug5-ga gi hu-mu-ni-zalag {d#}da-mu {uruda}dur10-tab-ba hu-mu-sig3-ge
en: The dragon-face (is) the dragon-face of a man, the dragon-face of a man causing evil approached heaven (and) the clouds bring no rain. He approached the earth, and the plants do not grow. He approached the ox, and its yoke does not open, he approached the stall and smashes its cheese-pot. He approached the fold and destroys the flock. He approached the lad and sapped his (sexual) energies, he approached the maiden and tossed away her towel. He aproaches the nurse with (her) charge and cuts through the (child)-harness. Asarluhi took notice (and approached his father Enki ...): "What do I know that your do not already know?" Seven times, mix milled barley on the back of the grinding slab, Seven times, mix milled barley on the back of the mortar, together with fat. Bind it with leather. (Recite) the Eridu incantation. Bind it on the neck of the patient. May Nintinuga purify her (surgical) reed, may Damu strike with his axe,

sux: {d}gu-nu-ra {gesz}dimgul hu-mu-un-du3-e tu6-enuru{+e2-nu-ru}
en: and may Gunura erect her boat-mast. tu-enuru.

sux: 1(gesz'u) 1(gesz2) 2(u) 1(asz) 1(barig) sze# gur# 1(gesz2) 2(u) 6(asz) 3(barig) 5(ban2) 4(disz)# [sila3 ziz2 gur] ugula lu2-gi-[na] 1(gesz'u) 3(u) 1(asz) 3(barig) [sze gur] 2(u) 1(asz) ziz2 gur 1(u) 4(asz) 1(barig) gig gur ugula lugal-e2-mah-e 9(gesz2) 5(u) 3(asz) sze gur 1(gesz2) 2(u) 9(asz) 3(barig) 3(ban2) ziz2 gur 1(u) 1(asz) 1(barig) gig gur ugula du-du-mu 1(gesz'u) 8(asz) sze gur 1(gesz2) 2(u) 3(asz) 3(barig) ziz2 gur 3(u) 3(asz) 1(barig) gig gur ugula lugal-{gesz}gigir-re 2(gesz2) 2(u) 2(barig) sze gur a-sza3 {d}szara2
en: 681 gur 1 barig barley, 86 [gur] 3 barig 5 ban 4 [sila emmer,] foreman: Lugina 631 [gur] 3 barig [barley,] 21 gur emmer, 14 gur 1 barig wheat, foreman: Lugal-emahe 593 gur barley, 89 gur 3 barig 3 ban emmer, 11 gur 1 barig wheat, foreman: Dudumu 608 gur barley, 83 gur 3 barig emmer, 33 gur 1 barig wheat, foreman: Lugal-gigire 140 gur 2 barig barley of the field of Szara,

sux: ugula a-ab-ba 3(gesz2) 5(u) 3(asz) 2(barig) 1(ban2) 5(disz) sila3 sze gur a-sza3 {d}szara2 ugula ur-{gesz}gigir? 1(gesz2) 4(u) 3(asz) 2(barig) sze gur a-sza3 {gesz}ma-nu ugula a-gu-gu 2(gesz2) 1(u) 3(asz) sze gur a-sza3 {gesz}ma-nu 1(gesz2) 1(u) 8(asz) 3(barig) ziz2 gur a-sza3 sipa-ne ugula lugal-x-a-ni 3(u) 7(asz) 1(barig) 1(ban2) 7(disz) sila3 a-sza3 sipa-ne ugula lugal-ku3-ga-ni 5(u) 4(asz) 4(barig) 1(ban2) gur a-sza3 sipa-ne 1(gesz2) 4(u) 8(asz) 2(barig) gur 1(u) 1(asz) 4(barig) 2(ban2) gu2-nida gur a-sza3 sipa?-x ugula ur-{d}en-lil2-la2? sze gesz-e3-a GAN2-gu4 da-umma{ki} ARAD2 szu ba-ti giri3 lu2-banda3{da} mu si-mu-ru-um lu-lu-bu#{ki#} a-ra2 1(u) la2 1(disz)-kam ba-hul
en: foreman: A'abba 233 gur 2 barig 1 ban 5 sila barley of the field of Szara, foreman: Ur-gigir? 103 gur 2 barig barley of the field of manu-wood, foreman: Agugu 133 gur barley of the field of manu-wood, 78 gur 3 barig emmer of the “field of the shepherds,” foreman: Lugal-xani 37 1 barig 1 ban 7 sila (barley) from the “field of the shepherds,” foreman: Lugalkugani 54 gur 4 barig 1 ban (barley) from the “field of the shepherds,” 108 gur 2 barig (barley), 11 gur chickpeas from the “field of the shepherds,”? foreman: Ur-Enlila threshed grain of the royal plots in Da-Umma did ARAD2 receive via Lu-banda. Year: “Simurum and Lulubu were destroyed for the 9th time.”

[...] un#?-na-an-gal2#? ugnim# x gu2# gar-gar-ra-na x [...] [bi2]-ib#-kesz2#? iri-bi? dili-dili bir-bir szu-bi {d#}utu di-ku5# [...] u3 an# ku3# [x] KA# na#-ah-he2-[esz?] lu2 tur-mu ni2-te-ga2 dingir#-ra# mu-lu a nam#?-[ti-la] [...]-ab-x-[...] nun {d}suen-i-din-nam ni2-te#-ga2 dingir-ra# [mu-lu a? x (x)]-ab#?-x [...] mu#?-x-[...] szud3? na-ag2-ti-la me-e mi-ri#-[...]-za em3?-x [...] ma#-ra#-ni#-ib#-[...] nig2-la2 si!-sa2 szu-za ma-ra-mar-re#? [...] KA#? mu-un-na-ab#-[...] aga3-us2 {gesz#}[tukul] szu-du8-zu e-ne-[x x] nam-ti-za em3#?-[gig?] [...] mu-lu ul3-la# i#-bi2-mu-sze3 x [...] KA#? BAD#? x [...] usu mu-lu gig#-ga# i-bi2-[...] gurusz {d#}da#-mu x nam-tar-ra [...] [nun {d}]suen#-i-din-nam u4 tu-da zi# [...] [{d}]ga#-sza-an-ti-la-ug5-ga# x [...] [nun?] {d}suen-i-din-nam-ma? igi x [...]
en: The mother of the king, pure Nininsina [...], To her beloved son Damu, the great physician of Enlil, [said]: "Great physician, you know the plant of life, [you know] the potion (?) [of life], Great physician, holding the cloth (?) of life, ... Your cloth (?) being the plant of life, ... Your cloth (?) being white linen, your destiny (?)... Before Utu, who loves to sustain people, ... The mother speaking a lament for the sick, wailing... Those who are sick (?)..., diseases (?), ... The sister, who is proud (?) among the young men, ...you cannot take away (?), Offspring and little ones (?), who listens to laments (?)... When he submits the troops...he binds (?). To scatter their cities one by one, Utu, the judge (?), and pure An ordered (?). My young man, who has respect of the gods, who [drinks (?)] the potion [of life] (?), Noble Suen-iddinam, who has respect of the gods, [who drinks (?) the potion of] life (?), A prayer of life I..., The healing (?) bandage he wrapped around your hand for you, ... Your soldier, who holds the weapons he (?) ..., your life (?) ... The one who holds the reins before me... The strength of the sick man (?) ... The young man, Damu, who [holds (?)] the...of destiny... Noble Suen-iddinam, when he was born... Nintinuga... At (?) ... Suen-iddinam...may she (?) look (?) [favourable (?)]

akk: 3(u) _ma-na ku3-babbar_ ni-is-ha-su2 _diri_ sza-du-a-su2 sza-bu sza da-da-a a-na ku-ku-la2-nim _dumu_ ku-ta-a ip-qi2-du-ma a-na a-lim{ki} a-na szi2-a-ma-tim ub-lu _ku3-babbar_ sza {d}en-lil2-ba-ni a-na-nu-um a-szu-mi3 {d}en-lil2-ba-ni eq-lam e-ti2-iq lu-qu2-tum isz-tu3 a-lim{ki}
en: 30 minas of silver—its nisḫatu (fee) added, its šaddu’utu (fee) paid— which Dadaya to Kukkulanum, son of Kutaya, entrusted, and which to the City for purchases he carried—that silver belongs to Enlil-bani. From here in the name of Enlil-bani the territory it will cross; the goods from the City

akk: e-li-a-ma a-szu-mi3 {d}en-lil2-ba-ni-ma eq-lam e-ti2-iq lu-qu2-tum a-na ka3-ni-isz3 e-ra-ba-ma {d}en-lil2-ba-ni i-la2-qe2-szi2 _igi_ ba-zi-a _dumu_ dingir-ku-ru-ub _igi_ a-zu-ta-a _dumu_ e-me-me _igi_ a-szur-i-di2 _dumu_ kur-ub-esz18-dar
en: will go up and in the name of Enlil-bani the territory will cross. The goods at Kaneš will arrive and Enlil-bani will receive them. Before Baziya, son of Ili-kurub; before Azutaya, son of Ememe; before Assur-idi, son of Kurub-Ištar.

akk: um-ma pi2-la2-ha-a ni-ma-a-szur u3 ma-num-ba-lum2-a-szur-ma a-na {d}en-lil2-ba-ni u3 ku-ku-la2-nim qi2-bi2-ma 3(u) _ma-na ku3-babbar_ ni-is-ha-su2 _diri_ ku-nu-ki-ku-nu ku-ku-la2-num ub-lam _ku3-babbar_ ni-is-ni-iq-ma 2/3(disz) _ma-na ku3-babbar_ im-t,i3 _sza3-ba_ me-at 1(u) 4(disz) _tug2 tug2_ ku-ta-nu _ku3-bi_ 7(disz) 1/2(disz) _ma-na_ 4(disz) 1/4(disz) _gin2_ 2(asz) _gu2_ 1(u) 5(disz) _ma-na an-na_ ku-nu-ku 1(u) 3(disz) 1/4(disz) _gin2-ta_ 4(u) _ma-na_ _an-na_ ku-nu-ku a-ha-ma 8(disz) _ma-na an-na_ ku-nu-ku 1(u) 3(disz) _gin2-ta ku3-bi_ 1(u) 3(disz) 5/6(disz) _ma-na_ 4(disz) la2 1/4(disz) _gin2_ 6(disz) _ansze_ / s,a-la2-mu 2(disz) _ma-na_ 8(disz) _gin2 ku3-babbar_ qa2-dum u2-ku-ul-ti2-szu-nu it-bu-lu 1(u) 6(disz) _gin2 ku3-babbar_ u2-nu-su2-nu
en: Thus Pilahaya, Nima-Assur and Mannum-balum-Assur, to Ellil-bani and Kukkulanum say: 30 minas of silver—its nisḫatu (tax) added—with your seals Kukkulanum has brought. We checked the silver and 2/3 mina of silver it was light. Therefrom: one hundred 14 kutanu-garments, their silver: 7 1/2 minas 4 1/4 shekels; 2 talents 15 minas of sealed tin (at the rate of) 13 1/4 (shekels of tin) per shekel (of silver); 40 minas of sealed tin, additionally 8 minas of sealed tin (at the rate of) 13 per shekel, their silver 13 5/6 minas 4 less 1/4 shekels. 6 black donkeys are 2 minas, 8 shekels of silver together with their fodder taken away. 16 shekels of silver their harnesses.

akk: 3(u) 7(disz) _ma-na an-na_ qa2#-tim# 1(u) 3(disz) _gin2-ta ku3-bi_ 2(disz) 5/6(disz) _ma-na_ 2(disz) 1/6(disz) _gin2_ 1(disz) _ma-na ku3-babbar_ be-u2-la2-at 2(disz) ka3-s,a-ri 4(disz) _gin2_ lu-bu-szu-nu 7(disz) _gin2 ku3-babbar_ a-s,e2-er be-u2-la2-ti2-szu a-na na-bi4-su2 nu-ra-di2 1(u) 2(disz) 1/2(disz) _gin2_ te2-s,u2-bu 2(disz) 1/2(disz) _gin2_ sza sa3-e-tim 1(u) 5(disz) _gin2_ wa-s,i2-tum 6(disz) _gin2 ku3-babbar_ a-na qa2-ti2 a-szur-ma-lik ni-di2-in 5/6(disz) _ma-na ku3-babbar_ ku-ku-la2-num il5-qe2 um-ma szu-ut-ma szu-ma / _dam-gar3 / ku3-babbar_ la2 usz!-<ta>-ak-szi2-da-ni i-na _ku3-babbar_ a-nim a-la2-qe2
en: 37 minas of “hand-tin” (at the rate of) 13 per shekel, their silver 2 5/6 minas 2 1/6 shekels 1 mina of silver: the working capital of 2 harness makers; 4 shekels their clothes; 7 shekels of silver to his working capital for Nabisu we added. 12 1/2 shekels, “add-ons”; 2 1/2 shekels for the sa'utum; 15 shekels the departure (toll); 6 shekels of silver to the account of Assur-malik we paid; 5/6 mina of silver Kukkulanum has taken, saying: “If the trader the silver will not let me receive here, then I will take it from this silver!”

akk: _e2-gal_ {disz}man-gin _man szu2 man kur_ asz sza2 {disz}3(u)-pap-pap _sukkal gal_-u
en: Palace of Sargon, king of the universe, king of Assyria; (property) of Sîn-aḫa-uṣur, the grand vizier.

akk: [a]-na# ma-ti-ma [a]-na# la-ba-ar u4-mi# [a]-na# u4-um s,i-a-tim a#-na u4-mi sza uh2-hu-ru3 _ki#-mah_ a-ni-a-am li#-mur-ma la u2-sza-sa-ak [a-na asz2]-ri#-szu li-te-er-szu [a-wi]-lum# szu#-u2 sea a#-ni-i-tam [i]-ma#-ru#-ma# la i-me-e-szu# ki#-[a-am] i#-qa2#-ab-bu-u2# [_ki-mah_-mi a]-ni#-a-am a#-na# asz2#-ri#-szu#-mi# lu-te-er-szu gi#-mil i-pu#-szu li-ir-ti-ib-szu i#-na# e-la#-ti szum-szu li-id-mi-iq [i]-na# sza#-ap-la-ti# e-t,e-em#-mu-szu me-e# za#-ku-ti# li-il#-tu-u2
en: In the future, in the days to come, in the days hereafter, in the days to follow, upon this tomb let him look. and not do away with it; may he restore it. That man who this sees and does not disregard it, says thus: “(As for) this tomb, to its place I should restore it,” may the favor he has done be returned to requite him. Above, may his name be blessed! Below, may his spirits drink pure water!

akk: da-mu-um / da-ma-mu-um ka3-al-bu-um s,a-al-mu-um i-ti2-li-im / ra-bi-is, u2-qa2-a _illat_-tam2 pa2-ri-is-tam2 et,-lam5 dam-qam / i-ta-na-ap2-li#-[sa3] e-na-szu ma-num la2-asz2-pu-ur a-na ma-ru-a-at e-a2
akkts: damum damamum kalbum ṣalmum ittillim rabiṣ uqa'a ellatam paristam eṭlam damqam itanaplisa enāšu mannum lašpur ana maru’āt ea
en: Blood, bloody, dog black on the ruin mound encamped, waiting for the caravan seperated, the man pretty espied with his eyes; whom shall I send? to the daughters of Ea

akk: 7(disz)# [u] 7(disz)#-ma [kar3-pa2-ti3]-ki-na sza sa3-am-tim u3 ka-ni-ki-na sza hu-la-li-im li-qe2-a-ma al-ka3-ma i-na na-ri-im [x]-pu#-ra ma-i [e-lu-tim] [...] na# qa2 al# [x] [...]-nim [...] [...] x s,i2-i et,#-lum2
akkts: sebe u sebema karpātikina ša samtim u kannīkina ša ḫulālim liqe’āma alkāma ina nārim ...-pura ma’i ellūtim ... ... ... ṣī eṭlum
en: the 7 and 7, your jugs of carnelion and your potstands of chalcedony take, and go and in the river ... pure water ... ... ... Leave, man!

akk: [a]-na isz-ri-ka3 tu3#-ur
akkts: ana išrika tūr
en: To your place return!

akk: _kiszib3#_ a-<szur>-qa2-bi4-a _dumu_ i-szu-hi-im
en: seal of Azubiya, son of Ishuhum

akk: na-asz2-pe3-er-tum# sza as2-qu2-dim
en: "order" of Asqudum

akk: a-ma-la2 di2-in ka3#-[ri-im u2?] szi2-ma-tim# sza# [...] _dumu_ a#? [...]
en: following the verdict issued by the karum (and?) the last will of (PN) son of (PN)

akk: um-ma a-szur3-na-da-ma a-na szi2-sza-ah-szu-szar qi2-bi-ma u2-t,a2-tam2 u3 su2-ba-ra-am ma-la2 i3-li2-i-szar u3 hu-lu-ba szi2-im ni-ga-li u3 _an-na_ sza a-di2-nu-szu-nu-ti2-ni-ma a-na a-la2-ni ub-lu-ni ma-la2 i-di2-nu-ni-ki-ni mi3-szu-um ma-ti-ma
en: From Aššur-nādā to Šišaḫšušar: speak! As to the grain and the subāru(-fodder), as much as Ilī-išar and Ḫuluba as the price of sickles and tin (collected), that I gave to them and to the City they brought—how much they have given to you why at all

akk: te2-er-ti2-ki la2 i-la2-kam szu-ma la2 i-du-nu-nim a-na bi-ti2-a la2 e-ru-bu-nim hu-lu-ba i-na ki-sza-ar-szi2-im id-a u3 i3-li2-sza-ar szi2-im _3(u) ma-na_ u3 _1(disz) gin2 2(u) 2(disz) 1/2(disz) ku3-babbar_ sza ha-bu-lu sza-asz2-qi2-la2-szu
en: is your report not arriving? If they did not give, my house let them not enter. Ḫuluba in jail throw! And let Ilī-išar the price of 30 minas of (copper) and 1 shekel 22 (grains) of silver that is owed pay.

akk: _4(u) ma-na uruda 1(u) tug2_ ku-ta-nu 4(disz)# szu-ru-tum sza _tug2#_ sza il5-qe2-u2-szu-nu-ni
en: 40 minas of copper, 10 kutānu(-textiles), 4 black ones of the textiles that they took for themselves.

sux: an-ku3#-ga gal-bi inim# ka#-na# nu-mu#-un#-{ti-il}til-le#-e-de3 = %a {d}a-nu el-lu# zi-kir# pi-i-szu2 la ga-ma-ru dingir gal-gal-e-ne ul-la a-ra#-zu-ga2 {zu}zub#-bi-gin7 ba-an-gur2-ru-usz = %a _dingir-mesz gal-mesz_ ina an-nim tas-li-tu4 gam-li-isz ik-tan-szu2-usz ba-e-du11-ga zi-da nun en ka-ba-a-ni ba-a-{du}du11-ga-zu e-sze = %a taq-bi-ma ki-na-at ru-bu-u2 be-lu4 e-pisz pi-i-szu2 taq-bi ma-ag-rat an du11-ga mah-zu sag ba-du ul-la mu-lu im-me = %a {d}a-nu qi2-bit-ka s,ir-tu4 ina mah-ri il-lak ul-la man-nu i-qab-bi a-a dim3-me-er#-e-ne-ke4 {en}inim-zu an-ki-a te-me-en-bi dingir na-me nu-sze = %a a-bi _dingir-mesz_ a-mat-ka te-me-en _an_-e u _ki_-tim a-a-u2 _dingir_ le-em-ma en mas-su3 usz gar ni2-te-na-me-en {sa}sa2-gar{ga-ar}-me te-am3 = %a be-el mas-su-u2 ma-lik ra-ma-ni-sza2 at-ta mi-lik-ni mi-i-nu ki#-sikil {d}inanna hi-li-bi mu-un-szi-in-kar-ra {a}a2-zu a-ri-a-an-szi-ib = %a ana ar-da-tu4 {d}isz-tar sza2 te-em-nu-szi id-ka i-din-szi na-nam gi-na-zu an-gin7 ze2-eb-be2-da da-gan-me-a zu-zu-ab-ta = %a an-na-ka ki-na sza2 ki-ma _an_-e kab-tu4 ina pu-uh-ri-ni ud-di-szi {d}in-nin dim3-me-er hi-li-bi mu-un-szi-in-kar-ra me-tesz2-zu szum2-mu-un-na-ab = %a ana _{d}min_ i-lat te-em-nu-szi hi-im-mat par-s,i-ka szu-ut-{li}lim-szi {d}ki-szar2 {ni-id-la-am}gidlam e-da-sa2 he2-na-nam mu-zu-a nir he2-{ga}galam-galam{ga-la!-ma} = %a lu-u2 an-tum hi-ir-tu4 szin-na-at-ka szi-ma ana szu-me-ka li-te-et-li ug3-{gu}ga2 u3-bi2-tab a2-ag2 {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki-ke4 szu-na he2-en-da-ab-tum2-tum2-mu{x-(x)-x-x} = %a li-is,-s,ib ap-pu-na te-ret {d}en-lil2 u {d}e2-a qa-at-sa lit-bal {gi#-ir#}esz2-giri17 an-ki{DI}-a asz-a-ne2 a-ba-ni-in-tab a2-{ga}gar-me ur he2-me-a e-sze# = %a lit-mu-uh e-disz-szi-sza2 s,er-ret _an_-e u _ki_-tim szi-i lu-u lit-ni an-na-ra inim-bal bar ze2-eb-ba-ke4! hul2-le-esz nam-mi-in#-gar = %a ana {d}a-nu na-pa-le-e t,u-ub ka-bat-ti ha-disz isz-sza2-kin-szum-ma ku3 {d}inanna-ke4 sza3 {si3-ga}sig6-ga-na {mi}mi2 zi mu-ni-in-du11 = %a el-le-tu4 {d}isz-tar ina t,u-ub lib3-bi-szu ki-nisz u2-kan-ni a2-ag2-ga2 nam-an-na-mu ul-he2 en-na nig2 se3-se3-ke-da-na = %a ur-ti {d}a-nu-ti-ia _an_-e nak-lu-ti sza2 la um-dasz-sza2-lu {bu-lu-ug}bulug ki-us2-sa-mu bar-be2 ab-hul-e ku-nu-de3 nu-ub-zu-a = %a pu-lu-uk-ki szur-szu-du sza2 i-ta-tu-szu szuk-lu-ta-ma ana t,a-he-e la na-t,u-u an-szar2 lugal-la sag-en3-tar-bi-me-en ud5-sag-be2 szu u-me-ti = %a {d}a-nu be-el a-szir3-KU-nu ana-ku# ri-kis-KU-nu ah-zi-ma zu2-keszda ki-sur-bi za3-zu u3-bi2-gi a-ga-zu nam-en-bi ak-ab = %a kip-pat ki-sur-ri-szu2-nu ana i-di-ka ter-ri-ma e-disz-szi-ka be-el bara2 nam-lugal-la-mu-sze3 ga2-na u3-bi2-galam-galam{ga-ga-la-am} an-ta-szar2 he2-gal2 : ti = %a ana pa-rak-ku szar-ru-ti-ia ga-na ut-li-li-ma ina e-la-a-tu2 tisz2-bi gaba-ra mu pa3-da-mu-sze3 {d}ki-szar2 mah-a mu sa4-zu he2-em = %a ana mi-hi-ir zi-kir szu-me-ia an-tum2 s,ir-tu4 lu-u2 ni-bit szu-me-ki-ma li-bi-ir zi-da-mu szu-um-du-um kal-kal-la-ki ka-dib-ba-mu mu-un-zu-a = %a suk-kal-lu4 ki-nu szap-tan szu-qu-ra-a-tusz mu-du-u2 pi-risz-ti-ia {d}nin-szubur sukkal me-te-mu za-e-da nam-ab-ba ak-a he2-na-nam = %a {d}i3-li2-ab-rat suk-kal-lu4 si-ma-ti-ia lu-u2 e-pesz a-bu-tu2 it-ti-ka# i-bi2-zu e-ne-eg3-mar dim3-me-er amalu-bi sag-us2 nam-sza6-ga he2-bi2-[ak] = %a ina mah-ri-ki e-gir-e _dingir_ u {d}isz-ta-ri li-dam-me-eq sa-an-tak-x te-me-en da-ri2 an-ki-ke4 gesz-hur gi-na dim3-me-er-e-ne-ka-ta# = %a ina da-ru-ti te-me-en _an_-e u _ki_-tim u2-s,u-rat _dingir-mesz_ ki-na-a-ti# sag-tab an {d}en-lil2 {d}en-ki-ke4 nig2 hal-hal-la ba-an-<ba>-esz-a-ta = %a szur-ru-u2 {d}a-nu {d}en-lil2 u {d}e2-a u2-za-'i!(IM)-i-zu zi-za-a-tim
en: Holy An, the great words of his mouth are not to be abrogated. The great gods bow down to him, like a curved staff, in approval of and in prayer to him. What you command is just. (Like) what a prince or lord has uttered, what you have commanded is obeyed. An, your lofty command takes precedence, who would say No to you? Father of the gods, your word, the foundation of heaven and earth, no god fails to heed it. Lord, you are the leader who takes only his own counsel, what should be our counsel? Grant your strength to the maiden Ištar, whom you have loved. Your reliable approval, weighty as heaven, make known (to her) in our assembly. Give to the mistress, whom you have loved, your combined divine powers. Let Kišar truly be the spouse equal with you, may she rise to the (equivalent) authority of your name. Moreover, in addition let her carry out herself the decrees of Enlil and Enki. When she alone has taken hold of the nose-rope of heaven and earth, she shall be our strength! For An, the pleasant conversation produced happiness. He in his goodness of heart treated holy Inanna well. The commands of my Anu-ship are the complex fundament(?) of heaven which cannot be equaled. My fixed boundaries whose exteriors are fearsome and know no approaching, I am Anšar/Anu, the king's helper, do take hold of their band. Do take for yourself the entire extent of their territory, exercise alone the ruling of them! Come, rise up to my dais of kingship and dwell in the heights! Corresponding to my called name, may Exalted Kišar/Antu be your called name! My faithful vizier, whose lips are prized, who is aware of my secrets, Ninšubur, my fitting vizier, shall exercise the status of father with you. May he (standing) before you constantly present auspicious words from (every) god and goddess. At the eternal foundation of heaven and earth and by the enduring designs of the gods, when, in the beginning, Anu, Enlil and Ea allotted the shares,
